review:
I bought it from another site (thing I regret). The thing I regret is that the other site was advertising $25 google play gift card, which I just discover to be an offer from Samsung and not the site itself, and I had to pay taxes that showed up at the email confirmation.
This tablet might seem overpriced, but it isn't. What you buy for $399 is a complete package which includes 2 year of dropbox (50 GB) for free... lets say $399 - $100 = $299. Now the tablet is like just costed about $299, -$25 google play gift card from samsung = $274. And now lets say minus Awesome note app which cost 5 dollars in iTunes, and the universal remote function... The price you pay is about $250 for this tablet + EXPANDABLE STORAGE!!!

Now lets talk about its performance:
There is no worry about this tablet having lag or anything on the matter, you can compare it to the iPad and Nexus devices and it would run at the same level, although it (Note 8) has more software capabilities. The camera is really kind of bad when you compare it to the iPad mini, or the iPod Touch 5G, but would do the trick in good lighting conditions.

The software really adds to the experience and utility of the tablet. The multi window function works without any fault. It is fluid and doe not cause problems. The S pen really can create awesome works and tasks much easier. Am going to download the PS Touch with the $25 gift card, and I guess the S Pen is really going to come handy.

Am sorry to not have a really good structured review, but I promise to update it after a month of the note 8 usage. I also want to add that I have had an iPad, iPod Touch 5G, Nexus 7, and a Sony Tablet and currently an iPad mini.

I definitely would recommend this tablet to any one, but especially to the people that are looking forward new innovative software. The s pen as a college student add a lot of functionality on my algebra homework (less paper to waist). If you just want a tablet for emails, apps and web browsing-- look at the nexus devices and iPad, but IF YOU WANT MORE THAN THAT!!!!t.. THIS IS THE TABLET FOR YOU. My review would be 4 times bigger if I explained every function of the s pen and the tablet it self. Feel free to ask any questions.

Great:
size yes the size is perfect for putting in your bag and taking up very little room
weight the note 8 weighs very little which makes it great for traveling and reading
screen: resolution is fantastic
Storage: the ability to pop in an SD card and have more space
task bar control just about anything without having to go through menus
notifications turn them on or off customize to your hearts desire.
Features, features, features, I am still discovering features
Buy the note 8 and Samsung will hook you up with 50gb of Dropbox for 2 years (sweet) and a $25 credit to the Google Play app store
Pictures I tested the camera and was pleasantly surprised to see that the colors were true to life and not overly saturated.

Good
Storage: why only 16gb with a price point of $399 this should have been the 32 gb model
Screen:  over saturation of colors
eye detection seems wonky sometimes it works sometimes it doesnt.
SPen can be a little overly sensitive

Not so good
Battery life on my iPad I can read about 40% of a book and only drop 5% in battery on the note I can read about 10% of the book and drop about 30% yes (yes I have optimized the battery)
remote control does not work, have tried everything
$399 for 16gb? that is a steep price which will send quite a few people to check out the iPad mini its main competitor

I am giving this a 5 star review because at the end of the day if you are looking for a great android tablet that can easily be taken with you anywhere, it is lightweight, has a great selection of apps, features and the S pen for those of us who like to scribble and draw.

After almost 4 weeks worth of use:I will not comment more on anything else I have written about below, suffice to say that battery life while excellent is still about 70% of what the iPad mini provides(I still get about 8 hours of continuous use and 16 hours of standby on average each day.) Beyond that, in all other aspects, this has been a superior device(for me at least) than the Mini, which I still carry around as a backup(mainly for tv shows,movies and when battery is low on the Note). Why? essentially because the screen resolution, reminders and use of widgets far outclasses the ipad mini. Seriously, if you currently have any kind of Android Smart Phone and are familiar with the quirks*, buy the Note 8. If you have an iPhone and do not care about widgets and getting reminders/notifications that repeat, can be autosnoozed and that you can actually hear...then stick with the Mini.*Quirks: The Note 8 and any Android device can have battery drain while on Standby if you do not tweak your settings and/or have poorly written apps downloaded. My advice is to steer clear of free apps sponsored by ads, since that is a major culprit: buy the paid versions or do not download. As to tweaking Android settings, there are many pages you can Google depending on the version of Android you have, but this is a useful site:[...] Size compared to Nexus 7: I am hearing Ad Nauseum about how much better the Nexus 7 is for the price. Well that is not valid, in my opinion, if only because the size of the two tablets is so different. Yes really: even though the specs say only one inch difference, there is a huge difference in viewing and clarity: the Note 8(like the iPad Mini) is the perfect balance between a 7 inch tablet which is too small to be useful for productivity, and a 10 inch tablet which is too bulky and heavy. Comparisons in price should take this into account, as well as the stylus,lack of SD card support on Nexus 7 and the superior battery life(especially during standby) of the Note 8. Comparing the Nexus to the Note is like comparing apples to iguanas- a slight exaggeration perhaps, but you get the point. Go into Best Buy to compare: the Note looks about 30% bigger compared to the Nexus...It isn't, but that is how much more comfortable it feels.

Update 8 on day 7: BATTERY LIFE- One comment I received was that someone was having only 3-4 hours battery life just using the S-Pen and no other app. While S-pen is a battery hog, that should still not be the case. I have to specify that I only have my brightness settings set to 35-40%(more than adequate even for video) and only turn on my GPS if I need it for directions(I get at least 9 hours of continual use). These two settings alone can easily double your battery life and is something I have automatically done on all my tablets for several years. Also, I have only the sound notifications I need turned on-for example I do not need Facebook, Ultimate TODO etc and other notifications, since my S3 smartphone handles those. Again, this makes a significant difference to battery life. Finally-the first day I received the Note I used it down to less than 5% and then fully charges overnight. Despite any other advice you may hear, I have always found a memory issue in batteries which is avoided by running down the battery as soon as you receive a device and fully charging it,then doing the same thing every few weeks. Battery life is always going to be subjective from person to person due to the difference in usage-but screen brightness,gps and notification settings are key factors for any user in preserving battery life on a mobile device.

Update 7 on day 6: One negative I do have is the amount of bloatware on the device 16GB became 9.8GB. Fine if you had 32GB to start off with...but since the only current model is 16GB that sucks. Anyway, the good news is that even having downloaded 50 apps and hundreds of pics, several smaller event videos and dozens of books, I still have 7.8GB left. Does limit number of movies I can watch from Google Play-DRM Issue with not being able to move these to SD Card. I could root but in the past that has caused instability(especially after system updates), so I do not do that anymore. I would be tempted to deduct half a star for the bloatware(Google magazines. Allshare etc) but some people do actually use these. But they should just make them removable instead of system integrated. Titanium backup can help you remove these, but again I do not really want to Root, but I knew this going in and did not want to wait for a 32GB model. 90% of the time I do not need more than one or 2 movies on my device, so I can live with that.

Oh, I almost forgot, the Samsung keyboard has a feature you may not have noticed, but let me back up a bit. My favorite keyboard ever is SwiftKey(on my Galaxy 3), but I do not need it on this device, since the built in keyboard does the same thing for predictions and learning etc(IMHO). But also, if you need to go back on what you have written to edit,you can just run your finger/stylus across the keyboard to scroll backwards or forwards, up or down till you get to the area you wish to edit. Much simpler and faster than trying to pinpoint with the end of your finger/stylus. i discovered this by accident, even though it is in a user guide somewhere I later discovered.

Update 6 on Day 5: The latest thing I have noticed, but did not mention yet, is the Smart Stay feature(under Display settings, default set to on). It ensures that the screen never shuts off while you are looking at it: so even if you have a 30 second screen timeout to save battery power(for when you glance quickly and then forget to turn off screen), you can read uninterrupted. It actually makes most sense to have a screen timeout of 1 minute for me I have found. Also, if there is a large amount of text on the screen, and you have a one minute timeout, the smart stay feature is phenomenal. I had not commented on this before, because i already use my Samsung S3 and so take this feature for granted. Turning this off is a mistake, since, trust me, you will use more power turning your screen on each time it times out otherwise.

Today I received over 80 emails, read them and dozens of weather alerts and emergency alarms due to flooding around here. This is about 4 times more in notifications than usual, but no discernible increase in battery usage over the normal usage I have mentioned below. I am going to do some intensive video watching over the next couple of days and post the results on battery life.

Update 5 on Day 4: With the Quad Core processor on this, it puts the Nexus 7 to shame. I can multitask at least 9 different apps with no noticeable lag or significant power drain. I read another review say that they drained 30% of the battery after reading 10% of a book. I read 30% of a book(150 real pages on Kindle app in 2 hours) with only 10% drain. So it is not so much how many pages you read but the amount of time it takes you to read, and the brightness setting. Don't get me wrong, the IPad mini(only one you should compare to due to size of screen)has significantly better battery life, but the Note is up there with the best of the Android tablets, and I will certainly trade some battery power against getting customization and widgets.

Update 4 on Day 4: I installed 7 more apps today-New York Times,Ultimate To-do,Slice, Ap-memo, Data Vault and a few others. They were all optimized for tablets, as compared to even a year ago when that was most definitely not the case. With better resolution tablets and Samsung increasing their tablet market closer and closer to 50%, developers are churning out tablet optimized apps like crazy. This will solve the only real issue I see with this tablet. Then Samsung should bring out an amoled screen version of this device and with a higher resolution-something like 1900 x 1200. Even though that will not be as high as the future retina display iPad mini- the difference will not be noticeable. A combination of a more user customizable operating system,more tablet apps and better resolution, will(IMHO) mean the iPad Mini, even with a retina display, will get a run for the money. Also, I would stress again, that if you are going to browse the web a lot-definitely pick this(with Firefox) over the iPad Mini. Why use a device that does not allow you to increase font size and be able to fit that to the screen? i hate that about Apple mobile products0THeir OS does not currently work with Textflow software.

Update 3 on Day 4: Battery life continues to be excellent. I have discovered that the S-Pen has an incredible utility, even if you are not a student. By pressing and holding on the microphone symbol next to the space bar on the Samsung Keyboard, you get a box pop up with several icons: Clicking the one with a capital T and and a pen on it, changes the input method in any App so that you have a scratchpad at the bottom to hand write. This is then converted into text. For longer emails or blogging, this is very useful. I also used it for shorter Facebook comments and jotting down smaller notes. My handwriting is not the best, but with a little practice I was able to be 80% accurate on the longer notes and pretty much spot on for the one or two line notations. I may not draw or take long lecture notes, but the S-Pen now had substantially higher value than originally thought. Also, it hands down beats a regular stylus for responsiveness, scrolling and smoothness. It literally is an extension of your finger, but with a much higher degree of accuracy and precision.

Update 2: This is really just to warn anyone reading the first review (most helpful one listed), that there is a comment there in the middle of the review, that says the Note is really fast to charge-in 1 hour. That is not my experience and I cannot see how that would be possible, unless the tablet is at 80% or something already or maybe if there are no apps apart from what are preloaded(though i cannot see that either)- which admittedly may be what the reviewer meant. However I didn't read it that way and I think others might not either. I got the charge down to 5%-at which stage certain protection protocols are built in(cannot be altered that I could find), so the screen remained dim. It took 3 hours with the unit fully shutdown to charge back to 100%. Just an FYI to anyone thinking that there is an amazing 1 hour charge time. Hope this helps.

Update 1: After 2 solid days of continual use I can say that the battery life is excellent in standby and while in use. It loses less than 1% per hour on standby. This is with WiFi AND GPS continually running, and updates for weather,email and other PIM apps running in the background. I get 15 hours of use per day with 7 hours on standby and 8 used continually for web surfing, reading, app store and downloading apps. Resolution is wonderful-screen angles superb at any angle. Better looking graphics than iPad Mini. nexus 7 and even pretty close to Kindle HD-despite the Kindle having much higher specs for resolution on paper at least. Samsung just make the best screens. I would,as other users have commented, not use this Note for intensive gaming, but RPG games run superbly and Google Play video looks just as good as anything the Kindle HD 8.9 can provide-again, specs are not everything, Samsung havedesigned their screems to maximize appearance and richness of video. Battery life when playing movies is great(compared to other Android tablets),I was able to watch 3 movies lasting 5 hours and still be on 60% battery. But i will test more, since in my previous experience, battery life runs down much faster when you get below 50%- a quirk of the Android operating system. This is an area where Apple still dominate with superior battery life. more to follow in the days ahead.

Original review:
FYI I got my device from Best Buy(barely 2 days ago) and since I am a Premier Silver member, I get 60 days to return. If you already use a Samsung S3, then this will be the perfect accompaniment: a very sleek, fast and eye-catching device-get Samsung's own smart cover for this since it is the best available currently at Best Buy(in white at my store) if you want the slimmest,lightest case that does not cover the bezel(my preference only).

I essentially got this to be able to read my blogs and news articles, surf the web, track calender,reminders, to do lists. I can do this on the S3, but this way I get to save my eyesight a lot more: which suddenly has become an issue in my mid forties!! I also have an iPad mini which I love-but on any iPad device there is an issue of hearing the alarms, customizing sounds and changing snoozes, auto snoozing and generally having nagging reminders. There are some Apple apps that can help but not many to choose from. Android does not have that issue because of the open source operating system. So I use the iPad mini for portability,surfing reading,email,video facebook and games, and my S3 smart phone for all the reminders and tasks etc-they still sync onto my iPad mini, but I hear the alarms and get the nagging reminders on my phone. The Galaxy Note 8 now lets me have the reminders,surf the web with a better Firefox browser that has text reflow for virtually ANY site, shop, read and take a few handwritten notes excellently(Facebook app is awful on Android-Feria on Ipad Mini is a dream). Unlike other reviewers, the S-Pen is only useful in a minor way for me, since I am not at college or studying. All the other benefits listed above make this worth it for me on their own. One of the best things is the use of the Firefox app-being able to turn almost any page into easily read text format only, with adjustable font,is priceless when so much time is spent on the Web. As is the ease of which you can zoom in on any page, and the text will reflow to the larger font and fit the screen(also syncing my Desktop web Bookmarks and history): Essential, but something no decent browser on Apple devices can successfully accomplish-so on my Apple devices I tend to use Flipboard, Taptu, Zite and other RSS readers to fulfill the News functions.

The reason I am deducting one star is threefold: The price should be $350 to match the iPad Mini(the only real competitor to this product IMHO); There are not that many Android Apps truly optimized for Android tablets-unlike Apple and the S-Pen still does not have its incredible usefulness shown because there are only a handful of apps written for it. I deduct only 1 star for all 3, since the S-Pen is NOT the main reason I got this Tablet and with software updates/more apps on the way, I know this will change-so i deducted only a quarter star for this, a quarter star for the price, but half a star for Android not having more Tablet Optimized apps. Gaming is something I do rarely,but I find the Ipad mini/ my S3 to be excellent for that, since the battery life is phenomenal on the Mini especially. I will write more about battery life on the Note, watching movies etc when I have used it a few more days. I certainly am glad that I purchased at this moment however and hope this helps everyone who is considering, but confused by so many tablets out there right now. If this has been helpful or not please vote accordingly. I usually answer any comments within a day or so when testing out tablets-which is something I do as a partially paid amateur hobby. I have owned or tested virtually all Tablets released in North America over the last 4 years.

Let me begin by saying that I typically do not purchase any types of technology at launch.  I made the exception in this case, because I believe in the ultimate usefulness of this product by Samsung.  I have owned many apple products and for a time, I did enjoy them.  However, I always grew tired of apple tablets and smartphones because I realized that they usually only work well with other apple products.  Furthermore, every iteration of smartphone or tablet was only incrementally improved upon by the company.  Apple makes very nice but linear products.  They offer a very streamlined approach to technology at all levels across their product line.  They are great, if you only wish to do very simplistic task; such as surf the internet, buy content from Itunes and apps via the app store. Ipads are great at content consumption but are equally as cumbersome to use as a content creation device.  This is truly where the note 8 shines.  It's a great bridge device between your smartphone and your laptop.  The S pen is what makes this tablet a winner.

Before any are quick to state that the Note 8 is overpriced relative to the Ipad mini or even the regular sized Ipad I ask you to consider the following:  The Ipad mini is quite literally built with the same internals as the two year old Ipad 2, which still sells at $399. The mini costs apple $115 to make and they sell it old components and all to consumers for the price of $329.  They are making a killing selling the same thing in a smaller package.  Is Samsung doing the Same with the Note 8 relative to the Note 10,1?  In my opinion, no.  The Note 8 is an improvement from the standpoint of a faster processor, better software integration with the S pen and what I feel is better build quality and increased durability.  The note 8 is a refined and improved version of the note 10.1.  The 8 has added greater functionality over the 10.1. these improvements to both hardware and software justify the price.  After all, the same individuals screaming about how costly this device is are the same ones that are willing to buy a mini which is only $70 cheaper than the dated and yet bigger ipad 2.  the tech which powers both the larger note  10.1, and now the 8 came roughly 8 months apart.  In short, this means that the cost of these components has not depreciated to levels which one could consider significant, when one considers the cost of manufacturing both iterations of this device

The apps argument is largely a creation of tremendous marketing skill on the part of apple.  There are few apps which cannot be found on both platforms and for those few I have always been successful at finding a suitable substitute.  I have found that a few android apps may lack some of the features of their ios equivalents...but these instances are dwindling inn number.  The same can be said of the app optimization argument.  Apple does a great job of creating apps specifically tailored to both the phone and tablet space but android is making strides to do the same.  I am willing to sacrifice the aesthetics offered by apple for the functionality offered by Samsung and android; specifically the note 8.

Finally, an additional point is worth the mention.  I always find it funny when people are so obsessed with bashing screen resolution.  this is an 8 inch screen and quite clear and beautiful.  It is not a 50 inch LCD.  How many pixels can you cram into any tablet screen, before it becomes pointless and frankly entirely ridiculous?  Yes, there are tablets that are cheaper with better resolution but these do not employ the use of a fully functional stylus.  My point here is that i'm certain that higher screen resolution would have certainly come at the expense of greater S pen integration, software and functionality. These are the primary selling points of this tablet.  The galaxy note 8 is the best production tablet on the market at any size.  Its feature set alone makes it a must have for either a student or business professional such as myself.  I hope this helps those of you on the fence about purchasing the tablet.  For me cost and expense are relative terms. Yes, for $400 you could buy a full sized Ipad. But at that size, ask yourself how much will you use the device?  Will you get your money's worth?  I for one would consider this money well spent because I will actually use this device quite heavily making it worth the cost.  This is something I could never say about any Ipad I've ever owned.  Hope this has helped.

---Update 12/18/2013 - I've moved all "updates" to the end of this review for easier reading---

My main reason for buying this tablet was/is to use it for taking lecture notes and reading books (college/work/technical books). I wanted something more portable than the Note 10.1 and this seemed to fill the void.

Since this product has only been out for a day (when this review was written), I've had a chance to play with most of the features but not all.  This review is meant for those of you hanging on the fence, unsure of whether or not this tablet will work for you.

First off, to save yourself some time, if you have no intentions of using the stylus for taking notes or modifying photos then stop reading this right now. The stylus IS the reason this tablet costs more than the competition and in my opinion it's worth the price.  Yes, there are more powerful tablets out there that are much cheaper but they don't have a stylus!  This tablet is designed for the person who likes to read/write and/or do artwork/photo-shopping.  If you don't need a stylus then you don't need to read this review (look at other products like the Nexus 7).

The Pros: Taking notes on this device is a dream (very precise, even for mathematicians)
-The hand-writing recognition feature is pretty darn accurate
-I can use Microsoft OneNote to take notes (yay!) See "comments" section for more info on this(page 2)
-Supports a 64GB micro-SD card (search Amazon for the Samsung card)
-The interface is snappy and the graphics are fluid (for the most part)
-Internet browsing and switching between programs is quick and smooth
-The device is easy to hold and is very lightweight
-The image quality is crisp, clear and bright
-Did I mention, I really love the pen and it's ability to glide across the screen effortlessly?
-The infrared remote feature is pretty slick and worked with my Panasonic T.V. without issue
-Comes with 50GB dropbox account (for storing and sharing files with others)
-Includes a $25 Google Play credit for downloading apps
-Very quick to charge (roughly 2 hours)
-Plastic finish is very slick and clean - Metal bends and scratches so pick your poison

The Cons:
-The price should be lowered by about $50 in my opinion because of the weak video card (see below)
-The device comes with Android 4.1.x and not 4.2.x (Samsung hasn't announced when they will release the "much improved" update)

***This no longer applies as I've found an app to replace this missing functionality*** -The following is a negative regarding Android and not the actual device: I made the mistake of buying a 64GB micro-SD card thinking I could store applications and games on it. Turns out, Android stripped out this feature and you can only put pictures, music and other "documents" on SD cards. So in short, the included 16GB of storage runs out before you know it (for power users). Save yourself the money, don't buy an SD-Card and use the DropBox service for storing all of your files

-The graphics card is kind of weak for playing graphic intensive games but this tablet isn't really meant for that. For example, I played "Real Racing 3" and my framerate was probably 20-30 FPS. Still playable but kind of choppy. Additionally, when I unlock the screen with the stylus, the "ink" effect can be sluggish at times with a noticeable frame rate drop. Maybe an update will fix this.

-Not really a con but lack of color selection(white)is kind of weak if you ask me - This can be fixed by putting it in a case.

Overall: I bought this device to take notes and it does that VERY well. I can write complex math formulas and draw nearly anything I can think of without pixelation issues or accuracy problems.  The stylus IS the reason to buy this tablet. Don't go off of the specs or other reviewers who have emotional feelings toward this device.  If you're serious about taking notes (college students and corporate employees), reading e-books and playing the occasional YouTube videos and browsing the internet, you found your golden nugget. I did A LOT of research to find a replacement for my convertible-laptop (stylus enabled laptop) and I believe the Galaxy Note 8 was the right choice.

I looked at the competition, even in the $1,000 price range and ultimately I chose this device. My complaint about the graphics card was to iterate the fact that this is not meant for hardcore gaming. Yes it will play Angry Birds and those other cheesy games but don't expect this to replace your IPad 3 or your modern smartphone. The graphic cards on those devices are way more powerful than what this little guy packs.

After thoughts: For what it's worth, you can go to Best Buy and purchase the tablet. If you think it's not right for you, you have 15 days to return it and get a 100% refund. If you're a "Silver" status member at Best Buy, you get 60 days to try it out. After using it for just one day, I'm sold on the device and plan on keeping it. Your mileage might very. But I believe the portability and the note taking features of this device far out-way the cons. Other reviewers compare this tablet to other tablets that don't even have a stylus. That's just not fair. That's like me comparing a wheel-chair (which has a specific purpose) to a bicycle (which has a different purpose). Yes, both will get you around but they are designed for specific needs and I personally feel that the Note 8 will satisfy those looking for a stylus enabled tablet at an affordable price.

***Update as of 5/7/2013*** Attention U.S.A. owners of the Galaxy Note 8. While we all know the U.S. version didn't get phone capabilities (3G data), I found an app on the Google Play Store (free) that allows you to make and receive phone calls for free. All you need is a wifi internet connection (Starbucks, your home wifi, etc) to place calls, and a Google Voice account (free). Firstly, go set up a free Google Voice account so you can get your free phone number (do a search on Google for "Google Voice".) Lastly, download the following app from the Google Play Store: "Groove IP Lite". When you run Groove IP, the application will want to link itself to your Google Voice number (assuming you set this up) and the rest is very seamless. The app allows you to use a Bluetooth device for making calls or the built in speakerphone. Enjoy!

People are comparing this to the iPad mini and the Nexus 7, but there is no comparison, as this comes with the S Pen digitizer stylus. It is a premium price for this feature, but I love the S Pen, I'm sick of capacitive styli, and I was willing to pay for this feature. If you aren't interested in having a digitizer stylus, then there are a host of 7-8 inch class tablets for a lot less money. If you want a tablet with this feature that's less that 10 inches, this is your baby.

I don't find the resolution to be a problem with any but the smallest fonts, and the system is powerful enough to be fast and fluid in every way. Other people have covered pros and cons fairly well, so I'll add some other things I noticed:

The Note 8.0 uses the same Micro USB cable and 5V 2 Amp charger that came with my Galaxy Note 2. I'm used to the proprietary connection on larger tablets, so this was an unexpected perk.

There's a lack of cases out there right now for this size device, but I have a Timbuck 2 sleeve for my old Kindle 2 that fits perfectly. The inside dimensions of the sleeve are 150 mm by 222 mm (5-7/8 inches by 8-3/4 inches), and it fits perfectly. You could probably fit it in a case with the inside dimensions of 140 cm x 212 cm, but you'd need some depth to the case (a sleeve that tight might not fit).

Update 1 4/24/2013
For reference, I've also owned the Asus TF101, TF201, and TF700 tablets. I currently use a Galaxy Note 2 phone; previously I've used a Galaxy Nexus, Droid 3, and Droid X. My impression of the Note 8 is based on comparisons to the other Android devices I've used.

Now that I've had this for several weeks, I absolutely love it. The size is perfect for taking with me to work, it's light and easy to hold for hours. The S Pen takes some practice to learn the commands, but now I can take a screenshot and make notes on it in seconds. The S Note app is the best I've used for handwritten notes, the palm rejection finally makes it so I can use a tablet as a notebook. You can import PDFs or images and make notes on them, and you can export them back out as PDFs or images. I've used the split screen a few times to make notes while I watch a video lecture, that feature is very nice.

Battery life is excellent for a tablet. I get about 7-8 hours of screen time use before it hits 25%-30% (my cutoff for plugging it in). Screen use is streaming Netflix, browsing the internet, playing games, etc. Standby uses almost no power. I haven't let it sit unused for more than 8 hours, but the battery drop is minimal. I did set WiFi to turn off when the screen isn't on, this helps out battery life on any Android device.

I've turned off the motion detection and eye detection. The eye detection had trouble with my eyes, maybe because I wear glasses?

The included IR apps are pretty useless to me. We don't have cable on our TVs- we use streaming services, BluRay, and gaming consoles. I have two Samsung TVs, one from 2009, one from 2010. Neither worked well with the included IR apps. There is an app on the Play market that is compatible with the Note 8 IR blaster (Touchsquid Samsung). At $19 for the home version it's expensive, but then I realized that the Logitech Harmony remote I bought a couple years ago was four times the price and died in 3 months. So, I bought the app, and while it has a huge learning curve, I can control my TVs, DVD, BluRay, Xbox360 and Roku devices with the Note. Very cool.

For the control freaks out there, the Note 8 rooted in seconds using Framaroot with the Aragorn exploit. THIS VOIDS THE WARRANTY. Unless you explicitly know why you want to root, don't do it.

The entire system is fast and fluid. There's no issue with opening a YouTube link, watching the video the switching back to the browser or app. My poor formerly beloved TF700 Infinity has barely been touched since I got the Note 8, because it had big problems with fluid transitions. Bluetooth connections to external speakers (Jawbone Jambox) and headphones (LG Tone HBS-700) keep the audio in sync with the picture, another problem that my TF700 could never overcome.

The Samsung keyboard is AWESOME! I love the swipe input and one-hand mode. Swipe input on tablets can be hit or miss, depending on the keyboard, but the Samsung keyboard in one-hand mode is small enough so swipe inputs can be done quickly. Also, it will automatically open handwriting recognition when the S Pen is pulled out. Previously, Swype was my keyboard of choice, but the Samsung keyboard is the most functional and comprehensive stock keyboard I've ever used.

I continue to see reviews comparing this to the iPad Mini and Nexus 7. I stand by my assertion that there simply is NO comparison. Neither has expandable storage, digitizer stylus, or IR blaster. The stylus and IR blaster are not must-have features, but they are 100% worth the price difference. It takes some time to really explore all of the features, but I'm impressed with the functionality of this tablet.

Bought this tablet yesterday to replace my Nexus 7. I've always used a stylus with my N7, as I've found it a great way to interface with a tablet (and also keep the fingerprints down). From the moment the Galaxy Note 8.0 was announced, I knew I'd be buying it. So far, I'm absolutely thrilled with my decision.

Pros:
- The screen is very clear and easy to read
- The tablet is very snappy, even after loading all my apps, I'm still experiencing no lag
- The weight is perfect - it's light enough to hold in one hand while writing with the S-pen
- Samsung has added a lot of user-friendly features to Android
- The S-pen is a stand-out feature if you like to write and take notes on your device

Other:
- If you're used to a device with on-screen buttons (Nexus 7 for example), it takes a lot of getting used to having physical buttons (and for some reason Samsung put the back button on the right side)
- Many have complained about the "cheap" build feel of Samsung devices. While this device is plastic, it feels solid in the hand, and the plastic makes it light and very easy to hold in one hand.  Since most are going to put it in a case anyway, the back being plastic really doesn't matter.
- The change between stock Android and TouchWiz is drastic.  If you've got a prior TouchWiz device, you'll feel right at home on this one, but if you're coming from Stock Android, be prepared for some adjustment.

Cons:
- Only minor con is the price, but the S-pen and the hardware/software enhancements required to make it work well justify the additional cost over a Nexus 7 or the other cheap Android tablets out there.

You can't really compare this to the Nexus 7 - it serves a very different purpose.  If you want media consumption, the Nexus 7 (or the other cheap 7-inch tablets) is a great device.  If you want a note-taking, document-editing work-device, this is a perfect choice.

I got this tablet to use in my chemistry class, because I needed to work out equations on my powerpoint slides. My handwriting is atrocious, and I'm super disorganized (papers everywhere), so the thought of having all my notes worked out on the saved slides seemed so efficient. This didn't work for that purpose in the word processor I got, which was the $15 windows compatibility pack from the app store(sorry I don't remember the name). The presentations I was trying to interact with were integrated with 'clicker' questions, and the formatting wouldn't stay on those clicker slides without getting distorted when I saved the presentation after editing, and those clicker slides were showing fun nautical shapes instead of the slide content. AHOY MATEYS! Clicker slides in powerpoint are already kinda wonky, so this was probably an issue with the clicker formatting and not just regular powerpoint formatting. Non-clicker slides worked out okay.
Also, when writing with the stylus in the convert to text notation under a powerpoint slide for notes I took in biology lecture, the handwriting recognition software was quite good, but if I hesitated very briefly in the middle of a word, it converted it to text too quickly, and I wasn't able to adjust the timer on it. Also, when writing on a powerpoint slide with the stylus, there was no eraser tool, so if I made a mistake, I had to wipe everything I had written on that slide clean and start over. It was very tedious.
I was able to get it to load Smartbook okay, though a little sluggish, and you have to download Adobe Flash manually( which wasn't in the app store). An easy google search fixed this.
Otherwise, this tablet is great. It's intuitive to navigate.
Every person is going to be dealing with a unique confluence of factors like program and software variability for what they intend to use it for, and this tablet was *almost* everything I needed, but I ended up sending it back and sticking with my chromebook for taking notes in class, and I got a $20 bluetooth 10-key to make it easier for me to get my equations down quickly during lectures in math classes.
I had zero issues processing my refund.

Also it lets you rest your hand naturally on the screen without impacting your document.  After I got it my husband and several friends had to have it. Before the tablet stopped working, I had purchased a Samsung Galaxy S6 phone and received a free Galaxy Tab 4 from AT&T.  They are both working fine so far.  I had planned on buying a Samsung TV but I will put off purchasing anymore Samsung products until they make good on this $299 Galaxy Note 8.0 tablet.

Update 7/23/2015.  Went to a best buy Samsung Kiosk and the rep there did a SMART factory reset and software upgrade.  It did not resolve the problem so the rep suggested I contact Samsung Customer Service for assistance.  7/22/2015 I spoke to a customer service rep who said that although I was 5 months out of warranty he would try to get approval for a one-time courtesy repair.  He told me to send in all my purchase info to their Bill of Sales Team.  The Sales Team calls me this morning and ask me to email the information, which I did, she reviewed while on the phone and repeats to me that I'm out of warranty and that the only way they could extend the warranty is if I purchase an extended one.  I told her that I was under the assumption they were reviewing to determine if they could offer a "one-time" courtesy repair, she said there was not such option.  She transferred me to the executive customer relations department which was useless and very un-customer service like.  As a result I will not be purchasing anymore Samsung Products, including the TV's I had planned to purchased.  I have no confidence in the quality of their products and certainly have no confidence in their customer service.

I did not buy my Samsung Galaxy Note 8 from Amazon (Best Buy), but I feel it necessary to write this review. I LOVE my tablet. However, after the KitKat update, my tablet is now a paper weight. The battery drains after about an hour of use. Constant overheating messages. The cable in the charging port has to be jiggled before it connects and starts charging the battery which then takes more than 24 hours to charge to 100%.  Having googled the situation, I realised that this is a common complaint and a serious problem for this tablet.  Note that this only happened after the KitKat update.  It appears that Samsung has abandoned the Note 8 and does not intend to do anything about the problems its customers face with this tablet.  Customers who bought the Note 8 are left with a device that does not function properly.  There will apparently be no update to Lollipop for the Note 8.  So far I am not aware of a fix for the battery problems this tablet faces.  The advice seen so far include disconnecting the battery and reconnecting it, replacing the battery and the charging port and wiping the tablet and reloading the operating system.

Aside from the battery problem, the Note 8 is a really good device and I really do not want to spend another $300 to buy a new device.  Has anyone else had my experience with this tablet?  Has anyone found a solution?  HELP!

This is a great little tablet, fast with a 1.6Ghz quad core processor and clear bright screen but has a serious problem if you want to use it as a phone, your SIM won't fit since it takes a Micro Sim!  I don't know why they couldn't have used a regular size SIM socket since it has lots of room but that's a big drawback if you want to use your existing SIM.  I checked with Frys, Best Buy, etc. but nobody locally had a SIM cutter so I had to order one on Ebay.  Another odd thing is that it has no Phone icon on the screen to use for calling!  There's a Message icon but I had to install the phone dialer app from the Play store.
The phone has some other minor problems too but they aren't deal breakers.
1. Cameras are terrible!
2. The screen is a finger print magnet.  After using it for just a few minutes it's so scuffed up that it looks terrible.
3. There is only one USB port and you have to use that for charging.  It's normal for a phone to have just one port but a tablet should have more, preferably one on each side.
4. The micro USB port is off center in the hole which makes it hard to plug in the cable and I noticed they sell replacement USB ports here on Amazon, that can't be good sign!
5. It doesn't come with any sort of case or sleeve but needs one, preferably one that has a tilt stand.
On the plus side this was the unlocked version that is considered to be a phone that costs $600-$1000, model 5100.  Samsung makes several different version of this tablet from the cheapest one that is just a plain WiFi tablet, model 5110 to the middle of the road AT&T wireless tablet that uses data with a SIM but is not a phone to the 5100 this is a full phone with 8" screen.  My T-Mobile SIM worked OK in the 5100 version but it will not work in the AT&T version even after it is unlocked because T-Mobile considers it to be a wireless tablet, not a phone, so it requires a special data plan with a different kind of SIM than a phone.  The AT&T version will work with a Freedom Pop phone SIM though.

DO NOT BUY USED VERSIONS OF THIS!

The product itself is arguably the single best android product I've ever owned, and I've owned more than anyone I've ever known. I've certainly owned all Samsung tablet products, most more than once, and most, several versions of each. It truly is just excellent in almost every way. The one down side is the bluetooth totally sucks--but considering the form-factor, it's handier with a stylus anyway. In every other way, it excels over every other tablet product, except maybe the note 3 and 4. Those are arguably better, and certainly the bluetooth works better. If ever you should attempt to use this product with Logitech's bluetooth easy-switch tech, do not judge Logitech based on it's ineffectiveness with this tablet, since LBES is one of the most reliable BT technologies I've encountered--and I hate to see the only reliable one I've ever seen get trashed.

ONE MAJOR WORD OF WARNING!

DO NOT BUY THE USED VERSIONS OF THESE TABLETS. I'VE TRIED TWICE, AND ENDED UP WITH WORTHLESS BROKEN PIECES OF CRAP.

Spend a few dollars more and you'll love it. Don't, and you'll end up kicking yourself. Right out of the box, the battery drains in 15 minutes, constant warnings about overheating, the home button sticks, and constant restarts for no reason.

I'll also suggest that Amazon corporate take action here. There's only so much of this your good name can tolerate without ending up losing customers altogether out of buyers remorse for something you're not to blame for--unless you sanction it through inaction. It also makes customers like me look bad for returning so many things--but what can we do with broken crap? We have to return it.

Amazon: PLEASE STOP LETTING SELLERS DUMP BROKEN PRODUCTS ONTO CUSTOMERS FOR A DISCOUNT.

The first time it was set up wrong.  Copied all the content from another Samsung account and I opted to just reset and start over installing only what apps I wanted.  The issue I then had was that it locked up and acted weird several times.  Also ran the battery down very quickly.  Didn't have that issue the first time so I tried again, resetting the device and starting over from scratch.  This time the install was smoother and I haven't had an issue with since.  We took a two week vacation and the device was used constantly by everyone in the family and the locking up issue as well as the battery dying very quickly has completely disappeared.  We have both the iProducts and Androids in our house and I can honestly say this is not the same build quality that an iProduct is, but I also don't like the restrictions the iProducts have and the features this little product has outshines those in my opinion.  Would I pay full retail for this device, NO. But at the price I was able to find for this one, I would do it again.

The Galaxy Note 8.0 is a great product. A few pros and cons:

Pros:

It's light and easy to hold. Coupled with the Fintie Case Cover ($15), you can set it upright at two different angles in widescreen mode. Closing the cover puts the Note to sleep and opening the cover wakes it up.

The touch screen is responsive yet forgiving of accidental touches.

It's fast. Cold boot is quick, and return from sleep is nearly instantaneous. I do a lot of multitasking and browsing with multiple open tabs. I was worried that it would slow down with all that information in RAM, but everything loads quickly. WiFi performance is great - better than my laptop, in fact.

You can set a password, a PIN, or a pattern for security. I like choices!

The three buttons - home, back, and menu - are very handy shortcuts. Press and hold the home button and it shows all open applications, making task switching very easy. (I discovered that by accident. Maybe it's in the manual, but I haven't read the manual yet!)

Volume control is easy to reach, and the sound is decent, although I haven't used it to listen to music (that's not why I bought it.)

Its USB cable allows you to plug it into a computer for easy file transfers, and the same cable also plugs into the AC adapter for charging. (I'm assuming you can charge it just by plugging it into a computer's USB port while the computer is on, but I haven't tried that.

Note-taking with the stylus is pretty good too. I haven't used it a lot, but it seems intuitive. The notepad application lets you draw "sloppy" objects (everything I draw is sloppy) and it turns them into perfect shapes. Handwriting recognition works well - you can convert handwriting into text.

Cons:

I'm bummed that the built-in calendar app doesn't sync with Google calendar in both directions. No big deal - just install the Google calendar and don't use the built in one.

The screen has an auto-brightness control and manual control options. Normally I want it on auto, and that works for most conditions. I've had a couple of times when the display was too bright, so I switched to manual and adjusted it myself. That's fine, but I'd like a shortcut to just the brightness setting. It doesn't have that. It has a "favorite settings" widget, but that takes up the entire home screen. Good thing there are five home screens, but still.

The cons are minor irritations. The pros make it worth buying. I recommend it!

Crack 2: straight through the microphone hole
Crack 3: between the power and volume buttons (closer to power button)
Crack 4: left side of device, about 5.5" down from the top (portrait orientation)
Crack 5: top left curve (portrait orientation)
Crack 6: top, just left of the S in Samsung (portrait orientation)
Crack 7: up to the headphone jack

At this point, none of the cracks seem threatening to compromise the internals of the Note. Hopefully I can afford to upgrade before they do. I've ordered a kid's tablet case with carry handle to get a better grip on it in the meantime.

I purchased a used Samsung Galaxy Note 8 from Ocean Reef Electronics, but it looks brand new, and has excellent battery life. Buying it used meant it was much cheaper than retail, so I'm extra happy with it. It's always a gamble to get a used product online, but I was pleasantly surprised that it barely had a scratch, and seems to be in perfect working order.

The used Note 8 from Ocean Reef did not ship with any Samsung product box or documentation - it only included the actual Note and a charger (likely not from Samsung). I'll probably get a different charger, as the one that came with the tablet from Ocean Reef is quite short, and has equal sized prongs (ungrounded/unpolarized NEMA 1-15 plug) on the charger, so sometimes the plug falls out of the electrical socket while charging.

But the Samsung Galaxy Note 8 itself is awesome - and I was happy it didn't look used, even though it was sold as used.

This is one of the best tablets out there - better than an ipad, and it does more. Android also has a larger installed user base than apple so there are plenty of aps both free and paid. The camera's on the Note 8 are excellent and the speakers are pretty incredible too. You won't believe how good they sound for such small speakers. Of course I use earphones to listen to music with the Note 8, but if I want to share something I play it through the speakers and when people first hear how good they are it floors them. Looking at a photo you just took on the large screen is nice too, and the cameras make using Skype a breeeze with great audio and video.

Many of the third party aps will sync across devices as well. I use my Note 8 for everything - calendar, recipes, shopping lists, to do lists, woodworking plans, drawings and painting. For example if you were measuring a window for shades, you'd probably draw the window and put in your measurements. With the Note 8 I take a picture of the window, drop it into Notepad and draw in the measurements right on the picture!

I have owned this device for almost a year now with absolutely no serious issues. There are a few things that I like and don't like so I'll do my best to break them down in a pros and cons list:

Pros:
-The stylus is the whole reason why I chose this table and I love it. There are no delays or stutters and it's very smooth.
-Lightweight
-Syncing - I have an HTC Android phone and this device syncs beautifully with my calendar and other Google apps. between the two. This brings me to my next Pro...
-The HD Note app (which I think use to be called S Note before one of the updates). You can create and sort lists but still have them synced to you S Note Calendar. This feature makes me want to get a Samsung Note phone so that I can sync it between the two!
-Streaming. No issues with buffering or anything. Not even after updates to the device or the app. Very nice.
-Customization - Everything from wallpaper to fonts. It's so simple to make it your own.
-Flipboard - Very cool app for catching up on current events that fit your interests.

Cons:
-Case options - I can't find a single case that I like due to ONE thing that has been an issue which is my next Con..
-The "home" button at the bottom. I cannot tell you how many times I here the voice command come on in my purse because even with a case the button is getting pushed and trying to perform a task. It's too bad that it's not an "inset" button like on the iPad. It doesn't matter how I change it's placement or get a new cover, it ALWAYS manages to get bumped multiple times. Annoying.
-Camera - It's not bad but my phone has a better megapixel. I have done some video but it just seems too bulky to do any of that anyway than just using my phone.

That's all I can think of off the top of my head. I'll be sticking with this device as long as technology allows me.

I bought myself this tablet because I'm in graduate school and needed to keep up with the technology. I ABSOLUTELY LOVE THIS LITTLE MACHINE! I went with Samsung because I have had a Samsung cell phone since I was 18 (so roughly 7 years), and I know it to be a great brand. I could have gone with the regular tablet, but decided to go with the Note because of that S-Pen that everyone was raving about. Best idea ever. I have to read a lot of PDF documents and the S-pen is extremely handy with highlighting and making notes in the document. I no longer print off anything because I can get the same experience on this tablet as I can looking at a paper copy. I have also stopped buying physical books because this tablet is wonderful to read off of.

As for the size, the 8 inch screen is perfect. I was concerned about getting a smaller tablet because I guess I didn't think I would get the same experience out of it or something equally asinine as that. This tablet is easy to fit into a purse, so I can carry it with me anywhere (or to work).

Honestly, I use the tablet more than my laptop, anymore. I can do virtually the same things without having to wait a while for it to boot up. The screen is very clear, and it looks very sleek. I've had it for about 9 months now, but it's as if it is brand new. My favorite thing about it is that I don't have to get things in print anymore, I can even write out my to-do lists, in my own writing, and mark things off as I go!

I am updating my review because the problem was solved by contacting Samsung Care. First, my device is still under the one-year warranty. The problem was my tablet's Multi Window was disabled. And there was no way it would be enabled unless it was completely reset up. This would wipe out everything I saved in it. The rep was very nice who understood immediately what could be done to save all my files before the reset up. I was transferred to someone who obviously performed the task from another country. She was very impatient with me. She quickly told me that unfortunately my tablet did not have this function. I told her I paid a lot more for the newest edition for the S Pen and multi window. It got to have this function. I insisted her do the remote back up of my files and then reset the tablet up. She sounded so impatient even though it took her only a few minutes to finish the task. The end result was good. I started my tablet all over just like when I first got it. I turned on the multi window button. And it worked!

FYI, the below is my old review. I hope it will help if anyone experiences the same problem.

I like the size and the good quality pictures of this Galaxy Note 8.0. Since I am not fast in figuring out some of the new features of this device, I have to wait for someone to show me how to use those features. I waited for almost 8 months until my niece showed me that the Multi Window can not work on my device. The key for this function won't be turned on. Basically, I spent much more money on this top tablet for one of the coolest features, but got it a default problem from manufacturer. I need to find out how long the warranty covers.

I had problems with this tablet when I first started using it. It crashed a lot and seemed to feel overloaded and can't handle some apps. The pen didn't last long either with normal use, but I had it replaced after much hassle with the 'techie' guy, so I was connected to Samsung Corporate Office, which sent me a new pen.

Then, something weird happened while I was at LAX airport... suddenly windows popped up from nowhere (like mirroring whatever I'm presently on... like one window, then smaller window inside it, then a much smaller window inside the smaller window, and so on and so forth, until infinity). They were just there blocking everything I was on and resembling everything on my browser. I couldn't work anymore cause it was blocking my artwork, my sketches and my writings and mimicking everything I was doing a million times over.

I contacted Samsung, but no reply. I messaged them on facebook with the image attachment... still no reply from them. I had no choice anymore... either to return it to Amazon for refund or reset the whole 'dang' thing!!! No one could fixed it, even the guy I met who was a computer programmer. He said he had never seen anything like it in his whole career. I also went to a techie guy in Studio City... said the same thing that it was weird and have never seen anything like it. So, it's no wonder Samsung didn't respond at all (maybe they have no clue how to fix the "monster" they may have created).

I wrote down all the apps I installed and some of them I paid for. The programmer guy told me not to reset it, and I didn't want to reset it either, cause that might not fix the problem and I'll lose my apps, my 'moolah' and still be stuck with the creepy stuffs lurking inside my tablet. Returning it to Amazon might also become a big issue, because I had it for awhile, plus I needed to use the tablet everyday and not wait... and so I RESET IT AFTER DWELLING ON IT FOR DAYS!

Boy am I glad I reset it! Why? Because, those creepy thingies went away and my Galaxy had been running smoothly ever since. Although, I lost many of my apps and what I paid for, but after explaining the issue to google play, they refunded me most of my money, so I bought the apps again.

This item was listed as refurbished, but it came in pristine condition and, so far works perfectly.  Also, the operating system upgraded to 4.4 Kit-Kat, within a few days.  This was a really great deal.

I've had my Note 8 for almost a year and love all the features and convienences it has over the ipad mini, in particular, the micro SD card slot ( the main selling point for me). The display is bright and very sharp though the auto-dim makes it a little too dim, for my eyes anyway. Speed and responsiveness is for the most part ok, but it does lag a bit at times. The two BIGGEST complaints I have with this tablet is that you can only use it if the battery is charged, even with the AC adapter plugged in, and the battery life is pretty poor (about 3-4 hrs for me). The AC adapter can not charge the battery and keep the tablet running at the same time. Also, with the tablet turned off and charging, it takes about 12 hrs to fully charge. With the tablet in "standby", it takes almost 24 hrs. I've gone to Samsung support about this issue twice and all they've done was replace the USB cable twice and tell me to keep the Wi-Fi and Bluetooth turned off because they put a big load on the battery. Kind of defeats the whole purpose of having a tablet I think. And yes, I've tried a different AC adapter, twice. So, bottom line, though I really hate to do it, I may have to go to the dark side and replace my Samsung with an (shutter!) IPad mini. At least it can pat it's head and rub it's stomach at the same time (charge the battery and run the tablet, lol). Almost Samsung, almost, but not quite there yet.

*Update 3/2015
After being let down by Samsung's service center, I decided to see if I could fix the charging issue on my own. With so many good reviews on this tablet, my particular one had to be a defective unit. Since I've tried several USB cables and chargers without luck, the next item to try was the micro USB connector in the tablet itself. I noticed that if I wiggled the USB cable, the charging indicator would come and go (not sure why Samsung service didn't notice this). I found a YouTube video that showed how to open the tablet without damage and that the micro USB connector is a separate module which is replaceable. So I found a replacement module from an online seller for $8.00 and replaced the (hopefully) defective one in the tablet. The new module appears to be updated with a metal reinforced contact support within the micro USB connector. The USB cable now plugs in tightly and is very secure. Previously, the cable would fall out if I picked up the tablet (not sure why Samsung service didn't notice this). The tablet now works perfectly! Unlike before, it charges fast and is able to stay charged with the charger plugged-in even with the tablet running processor intensive apps. Gave only 4 stars because I was left on my own to troubleshoot and repair my tablet.

I first ordered one of these tablets (of a different color) for my mother for Christmas.  I wound up picking out what I would have purchased for myself if I were to buy a tablet for myself at the time. After I became more familiar with her tablet's features I determined that I could no longer put off purchasing a Galaxy Note tablet for myself. She had been using hers for over 4 months, with no issues, before I ordered mine about 3 months ago. She has still not had any issues.

I have had my tablet for nearly 3 months and it has worked great.  It currently find myself using this device a lot at work to scribble down notes when I am doing IT work on computers. Before I used it at work I had purchased it with the intention of using it for lists and notes that would otherwise be scattered about the house.  Now I can keep them in one place without having to worry about running out of pages or picking up the wrong notepad.
The added stylus is great tool. It is extremely handy if you like to take screenshots of pages or applications that you are working in at the time. I am able to fit the tablet into the cargo pocket of the shorts or pants that I am wearing and take it on the go. That would not be possible with a 10" tablet. I use an Otter Box case and it still fits into my cargo pockets just fine.
My most used application is S Note, and it comes preloaded on the tablet. The application is designed to work with the S Pen and it works well. The S Pen is more than just a stylus, and in fact isn't a normal stylus. It cannot be used on other touch screen devices that are not designed to use the S Pen. There is a slot in the side of the tablet which can hold the S Pen securely when not in use. Stowing the S Pen away can also save some battery life because the tablet uses energy to detect the S Pen. The power used to detect the pen seems somewhat negligible, but I like to put the pen quickly away when I am not using it so that I don't lose the pen.
If my tablet were lost or destroyed, I would not replace it with a tablet that used only a normal stylus. I use this tablet nearly every day.

Purchased in Feb 14 to replace an 18 month old Nexus 7. Only reason for replacement was to upgrade (gave the Nexus to our daughter which she is still using). After 3 months (in a case) my wife took the note out of her purse and noticed a thumb size black spot n the screen. Within a day it had grown to a 2 " wide black line across the entire width of the screen. I uploaded the issue on Samsung's web site (with images) and received a call (which I missed) the next day. I returned the call (to the number that was left)and got a machine so I left a message. After 2 days of no return call I called Samsung's 800 number and spoke to a nice lady who gave me the return info. She also stressed that I should have the piece "professionally" packaged by UPS to ensure no shipping damage (which I did). She was very understanding and led me to believe that my issue would be warranted. After 5 business days the tablet was received at the service center and on the sixth day I received a call (which I missed) and had a garbled barely legible message stating that the issue with my tablet would not be covered due to customer damage. Now the fun begins, I call the number back (2 minutes after the missed call) and get and all circuits busy signal on their end, I call back 10 minutes later and got a machine on which I leave a message and I call back again one hour later and leave another message. I then call Samsung's 800 number and am given to their escalated service department and speak to a very apologetic woman who merely reads me the report. I cannot understand how a tablet can have internal damage without a blemish on the outside. She continually tells me she is not a tech, but they are standing behind what their servicer reports. I request a photo showing any kind of external damage that would result in an internal screen error and am told the servicer is closed and I need to call them back the next day. Long story short, I convinced the lady to email my request to the service center and ended the 1 1/2 hour conversation. The next day at around 11:00 I call the servicer and again get a machine and leave a message, I repeat this process 2 more times during the day and that evening when I had not received the images or a return call I called Samsung and was told that the images had not been uploaded and was given another number for the servicer. When I called them I was told they were uploaded and I could log on to the service site and view them. Needless to say there were no pictures so back I go to Samsung. On this call I am connected to a woman who again apologizes an awful lot, but does nothing, in fact she tells me that yes the images were uploaded, but they were loaded to the wrong account and are proprietary between them and the service center and I cannot see them. All she wanted to do was set up a UPS claim. When I request to speak to a supervisor I was told there are none available and I asked to wait. After one hour and twenty minutes of holding a supervisor comes on the line and we spend twenty minutes going round and round with him telling me the same proprietary story I just heard (after his department made the original request for me). He continually states that Samsung WILL NOT REVERSE the service centers decision (when I never one requested this, all I requested was to see an image showing some kind of external damage that could lead to the issue I was having). He finally put me on hold and spoke to someone at the Service center (this was over an hour later than the previous night when they were "closed") and requested I be sent an image of the external damage. The next day I did receive an image and it was basically an exact blurry duplicate of the original image I sent with the service request. No sign of external damage, no bump, no crack, no bruise. Later that same day the supervisor called me to inform me the same thing he had stated numerous time the evening before " SAMSUNG WILL NOT REVERSE THE DECISION OF THE SERVICE COMPANY", like I didn't see that coming. This was undoubtedly the absolute worst customer service I have ever received in my entire life. Samsung and their service center have no concern for their customers and apparently believe that what ever they say goes and have no burden of proof on their end. THIS WAS THE FIRST SAMSUNG PRODUCT I HAD PURCHASED AND WILL DEFENITLY BE THE LAST!!!!!

I've had my Galaxy note 8 for over a week and I have to say I'm pretty happy with the device. I take a lot of notes and this device seems to be great for taking notes. I did extensive research for tablets with stylus support, even looked at the iPad mini and the Evernote stylus, but was not convince with the amount of apps designed for stylus support. I also did not want to get locked into using just Evernote on the iPad. With the Note 8.0 I have the capability to take written notes using various note taking apps.

I would definitely recommend this tablet for anyone who takes notes and needs that ability to share them. This is not your average tablet, it's mostly aimed folks who take notes, draw, sketch, color and so on and so on.

If you are looking for an average tablet for casual internet browsing or checking e-mail, I would recommend getting a tablet like a Nexus 7 or a Samsung Tab.

I was the owner of the Galaxy Tab 2, which is a 7 inch tablet. My main issue with that tablet was the limited onboard storage of 8GB.
Granted it did offer expandable space with the min SD, but 8 GB fills up quickly.
The Note 8.0 has 16 GB, though really ~6GB are used by Android. Perhaps there is a way to trim this, we'll see. More onboard storage gives me more confidence to locally store the 2GB of important documents that I need access to. The device also features the expandable mini SD, so I have plenty of space for media.
The 8 inch screen makes a nice difference on viewing movies, playing the Tower Defense games that I enjoy, and even in the viewing of .doc or .pdf files. The S-Pen has become my primary mode for data entry and I use the tablet for all of my meetings and note-taking, it is that effective. I also author blog posts using the S-Pen.

Overall, two BIG thumbs up on this device.

I use my note 8 mainly for work, at which I take a lot of notes.  I really enjoy the writing and pen feature of the device, but the battery life and the overall performance of the device makes me jealous of others that are at work who mainly have ipads or ipad mini's.  The overall user experience is a bit choppy.  Some apps that exist on both ipad and android tablets work smoother and faster on my colleagues' ipads (accessing hospital electronic medical records), and there just seems to be more support for the ipad versions of things than android.  This isn't a knock on all things android.  I like my device and plan to continue to purchase android devices (probably beyond Samsung now).  I just wish this device were snappier and the battery performance were better.  To give an example of the battery being poor, I've once unplugged my device at 6am after charging overnight, and by 10am, the battery was in the red after using the pen to write some notes for about 2 hours at 50% brightness.  It's a weird issue because it doesn't always happen, but does occur occasionally.

The overall feel that I'm getting with this device is like when I first bought a Galaxy S1 (Verizon Fascinate) and felt that it lagged behind the iphone version at that time but after upgrading to the Galaxy S3, the device felt much improved and much more on-par with the iphone version at the time of the S3 release.

I bought the Samsung Galaxy Note 8.0 for upcoming travel abroad so I could check my email, news and read books while traveling.  Laptop too big and bulky for personal travel.  Using an Android or I phone overseas is expensive due to roaming fees, but with a tablet you just need a WiFi connection, which are generally free.  So a tablet is perfect for travel. The 8.0" Note is the perfect size for travel also ... the 10 and 12" sizes would be too big and bulky.
It didn't take long to get the tab setup for my email account, homepage, and other apps I use on my laptop ... just a bit of learning curve.  Once I was setup,  I found that the tablet was a great substitute for my laptop with mobility in my house and outside wherever WIFI is available. When I was doing research for the tablet, I ran into a IT guy at a computer store who said he uses his tablet much more than his laptop when he's on off site location, which is what I am finding.  So even though I made the purchase for travel, I find the tablet is so much better than I 1st thought ... A GREAT BUY!!

I love the stylus to death. I would never purchase a tablet without a feature like the S-pen after being spoiled by it. The tablet is a little inconsistent on the precision of tapping with the pen - usually it taps right where you want it to, but sometimes it is a pain. At any rate, the pen draws very smoothly. My only complaint is I wish the Multi-Window feature supported more apps. Not even Google Drive is supported, which is a huge bummer for me since I use that app more than most. Hopefully in the near future Drive and Firefox will join the list of apps supported.

I'm a writer, one who finds she's more productive writing longhand rather than typing directly into a file. So I've been writing longhand, and then typing my work into a file which is A) time consuming, and B) double wear and tear on hands and wrists.

Now I don't have to do both. =)

With the S Pen, Dropbox, and MyScript Stylus app, my Note has become a writer's dream tool. I write, it converts to text directly into the story file I'm working on, and every time I hit save, it's uploaded to my Dropbox.

That's all I wanted it for: a dedicated writing device. It's perfect for the job, not too big or heavy, and not so small that it's difficult to write on the screen.

I do have a few songs loaded on it, so that I can listen to music while writing, and the sound's really good for such a device.

The cons are few, and the main one would be all the dang pre-installed apps that you can't delete. I intensely dislike having stuff on my devices I'm never going to use, and would rather have the storage space free. However, I've grown accustomed to it on my phone, so I guess I'll do the same for my tablet.

The other con is the size of the stylus. I realize it's made to fit in the tablet, but you'd think a tool meant for frequent usage would be designed to be more comfy to hold and use for long periods of time. It's not, so you may have to take frequent breaks to stretch your hand. The solution is to buy a "cover" that converts the stylus to regular pen size (which I've done).

All in all, I'm extremely pleased with my purchase of this tablet, and am looking forward to using it for a long time.
