Although I was hoping for an product refresh to bring the Note 8 up to the "Note 10.1 2014" spec range, I didn't see that coming from Samsung any time soon.. so I purchased the current model.  This was an afterthought to an ongoing adventure with the to-date miserable Dell Venue Pro 8 stylus*.  The Note 8 will update itself to Android 4.2.2, which is good news.  And although it appears only the 16GB version is out there now (at least in Wifi only) you do have the option to install apps to the MicroSD card.  The 8" form factor is, in my opinion, a better size for note taking with the pen than a 10" or 12" tablet, although they are likely preferred for those with artistic tendencies.  This will be a productivity tablet for me.  Using Papyrus and the included S-note, I am very happy with this device.  It is a touch tablet until you need the pen, and a pen tablet when you want to take a note.

The limitations of no native pen support in either Evernote or Onenote is disappointing, but not a show stopper for me.  Several pen apps will export or sync to Evernote, although so far I have found that integration is not as tight as you might hope.  But, Samsung did a very, very good job of the pen implementation here and if you are going to look to the tablet more than you look for what the tablet sends to your laptop, this is your device.

The screen resolution spec is on the low side, but it is not noticeable.  I have found that in these 7-8 inch tablets, high end resolution specs may be overkill at least in everyday productivity tasks.  Comparing an iPad Retina, Venue Pro 8, and Nexus 7 2013 the only practical difference I see is screen brightness, rather than resolution.  Basically, I can illuminate a large room with the Dell or Nexus, but all are acceptable in normal usage.  Outdoors, you will favor the Dell or the Nexus.  So basically no complaints about the screen at all but I wouldn't mind a brighter one.

So my conclusion here, if you need a pen-input productivity tablet and are happy keeping most of the information "on tablet" don't hesitate.  If you need Onenote with pen input, go look at the Asus Vivotab and the Windows world, or anticipate the hoped for "Surface Mini" later in 2014.

-------------------------
*Update on Dell Venue Pro 8.  Dell, without any request from me, send me a new revision active stylus.  Bravo Dell. The new version seems very usable with onenote, although it is a step down from the s-pen as expected.  As to the Samsung Note 8... I love it.  I have owned productivity devices since Newton, and this is probably the tops.

Since I love my Galaxy Note 2 (and I am an S Pen user), I wanted my next tablet to be a Note 8.0. A factory refurb for under $200 sealed the deal. I was disappointed that the 8.0 did not have some of the simple features of my Note 2:  No LED notification light when you have a message/email/etc.; no S pen keeper which sounds an alert and shows a pop up when you walk away with your device without attaching the S Pen; none of the cool writing features where, for example you make a written mistake and you can cross a line through it to delete the text or draw a line between letters to make a space. On the 8, you have to erase the entire word using the back button.  Also, the S Pen on the 2 pops out easily when you push it; the 8 requires you to really dig it out of its hole! Perhaps most of this can be fixed with a simple Android version upgrade (mine is 4.2.2)

The good stuff:  Unlike the Note 2, the S Pen does work with the settings and return buttons at the bottom of the tablet (on the Note 2, you have to press it with your finger which is a pain with pen in hand).  The S Pen is slightly longer on the 8.0 which makes it easier to write.  The larger space to write has really helped my accuracy. and has me more interested in S Notes. It boots up quickly and is very responsive.  The size is perfect for portability (though a tad heavier than I anticipated) particularly for using the pen while holding it. The picture is sharp though I am still prefer my Kindle book when reading books.

Overall I am very happy with the tablet and I hope the next Android  software upgrade will bring some of the features I love in my Note 2.

It's probably the one of the smallest tablets out there that has a Wacom digitizer.  I personally felt like I should have gotten one with a larger screen (like the Note 10.1), since I'm physics student.  The writing is not as precise as pencil on paper, nor as fast (it has a small but noticeably latency).  My best analogy would be that the precision is somewhere between a sharpy and a ball pen.  Still, it allows me to save paper.  If you want a tablet for drawing, you might want something larger too, unless it's just for fun.

Still, I reckon the small size of the tablet has its perks.  Its battery size is half that of the 10.1, and the battery life is only a few hours shorter.  So while it might not last you as long on a full charge, it takes less time to charge it.  Usually an hour or two is enough to get the Note 8 from almost 0% to 100% battery life.  You get more battery life per hour spent charging it compared to larger, battery hungry tablets.

For the purposes of keeping memos, however, it's pretty awesome.  Everything is digital, so you don't have to worry about having a mess of disorganized flash cards or post-its around your desk.  Cutting and pasting is not that smooth, but possible.

The Android OS is iffy.  While it's a nice combat OS that allows widget customization and multiple pages for your home screen, it lacks the same productivity as a Windows (especially if you're used to Windows).  You'll probably have to go out of your way to find apps that allow you to convert one file type to another.  Some apps won't even allow you options to open from, or save to a directory, but rather require you to "share" it via Google Drive or some other method.  Organizing files is certainly less efficient because of this.  You'll also have to go out of your way to find apps (sometimes pay for apps) to allow the same functionality that you can get for free on Windows, like writing programs in C++, and the capabilities will still be limited (console applications).  It does come with Polaris Office, which allows you to create document, spreadsheet, and presentation files, albeit with derpy compatibility with MS Office.  Sometimes symbols come out wrong, or the formatting is not conserved.

The tablet screen, imo, is large enough to view full web pages (as opposed to mobile versions of the same pages), since it does have pretty good resolution.  Plus you can always zoom in if things are hard to see).  However, you'll have to go out of your way to make Youtube videos work on Desktop mode.

For the Note 8 - No support for Java.  No gyroscope.  No flash (for taking pictures).  :(
The back camera protrudes out from the back surface.  Solution - get a case.
The IR blaster sucks (my TV won't detect it).
The GPS is hard to use (Google Maps requires online connectivity, so either save an area of your map for offline use, or get an SMS version of the Tablet).  There are navigation apps, but the free open source ones have missing streets, while the more complete ones will cost you.  I've personally stuck to using a dedicated GPS device.

There is a slot for micro-SD card.  You can also buy an on-the-go device to connect the micro-USB port (same port for charging) of this tablet to a USB flash drive, or SD card.  :)

The bottom line is it's a great tablet for the price.  It does everything that any other Android tablet does (with the exception of serious gaming) and has an S-pen.  The screen size may not be ideal for doing math problems or more advanced art projects, but it gets the job done.  A lot of the neat features (Java, Gyro, Camera Flash) aren't present, but the tablet is compact and has a quick battery charge time (though not necessarily life, but enough to last you about a day per charge).  It does give you the Office capabilities, but specifically for spreadsheets, I much prefer working on Excel on a laptop or computer with a mouse (and a larger screen).

I just love this tablet so much I have to write a review on it. Due to (and some provided by) my job, I have an ipod, ipad, a windows laptop, a macbook pro, and only recently I've gotten into android products, and I have to say that I love the openness of android.

First of all, when I got the note 8.0, I have to say I both loved and mostly hated it; hated it because of all the bloatware and useless (to me) apps that Samsung puts on the tablet; I loved it because of the wacom pen, which is very precise. Moreover, you can use ANY wacom tablet pen with the tablet, not just the small pen that comes with the note. I use a very nice wacom pen from an old Fujitsu tablet pc. I have the Wacom "Penabled Tablet Pc Eraser Pen" which is nice as well and is large almost like a regular pencil. The pen can easily be used to take notes in class, especially with LectureNotes (which I used on a daily basis).

To get rid of the bloatware, you can get an app called Clean Master from the android app store and if you open it up and go to app manager, you can disable (not uninstall) all the useless preinstalled apps (there is a category that says "completely safe to disable apps" and you just disable them, one after another). Of course, you can also go to app manager and do the same, but Clean Master makes it so easy. This is OK and it left a fairly nice tablet without a lot of the bloatware.

However, I ended up voiding the warranty because I rooted the note 8.0, then I installed a custom recovery (Philz touch), then I installed cyanogenmod 11. Now I have to say that I absolutely love the note 8.0; it's my favorite computer. The wacom pen works perfectly, and the tablet is 100% pure with no traces of bloatware whatsoever and it runs smooth as silk. (The original Samsang had over 50% of the ram being used even without installed apps running, while with cyanogenmod 11, only 17% is used.)

I would have never written this review, except that I did install the custom ROM (cyanogenmod 11) and the Samsung works like the dream tablet I've always wanted. Without installing the custom rom, I would give the note 8.0 a 4/5 instead of a 5/5 because of the bloatware.

Pros:
  - The pen
  - The Screen
  - Solid tablet in all other respects

Cons:
  - Slippery glossy back
  - A bit big
  - Price (but as a refurb, the price issue went away)

Being older (though quite technical), I really never fully made the jump from handwriting to thumb typing. Having the ability to write my notes is much more intuitive to me that to hunt and peck at an on screen keyboard.  But, all the capacitive stylus hardware and software I have tried is crude and inaccurate. Basically a waste of time.  So I thought I'd give the Galaxy Note a try.  I have always wondered why, if Palm could make it work (albeit with a shorthand language) 15 years ago, why couldn't someone make it work really well today, given the advances in software and processing power.  Well, Samsung seems to have done just that.  So while in other respects this tablet is really not noticeably different than other 7/8 inch tablets, for me, the pen really makes a difference.

So why only 4 starts?  First, I reserve 5 for near perfect only, and this is great, but has a couple issues:  1) the smooth glossy back. It may look pretty, but it doesn't give much grip. I prefer my (now given away) Nexus 7 in that regard.  2) the size - while 8 inch does give noticeably more screen size, it goes from being easily hand held, to marginal - really a bit big for long term holding.  I don't have huge hands, but their not tiny either - probably average to slightly large for men. I could see this bordering on being a two hand device for women.  Again, I prefer the 7" nexus in this regard.

But in the end, the pen makes the difference. And as I bought this as a refurbished unit, at a deep discount - total price close to new "normal" tablets, I am quite happy.

The note 8 is the most disappointing Samsung product I've purchased to date, the battery life is dismal, the most recent firmware update disabled the MHL and the stylus detection and calibration are so bad there isn't an English word to describe the level of dysfunction it creates. I'm really sorry I bought it, the Tab 2 or 3 7.0 editions are far superior as consumption devices and if you want the stylus function specifically just bite the bullet and get one of the 10.1 versions, all of which are superb, I cannot stress enough however just how angry I am at this waste of cash and think you should avoid it.

I purchased Samsung Galaxy Note 8.0 (white) about 6 months ago, and so far,  I have never had any problems with this tablet.  I like how thin it is and that it is faster than Galaxy Tab series.  But I do wish that its screen had a better resolution.  Although I can read small texts, they are not clear enough to read Web pages,  at least for me.

The 8 inch size is great for reading and working. Not as small as a 7-inch, but not as big as one of 10. Buy this tablet primarily to read and paint. Reading is quite good, and the pen works great. The tablet is very powerful with quad-core processor and 2GB of RAM. The display has a maximum brightness level of amazing, and is very colorful. It is not Full HD, but it looks pretty good, and I really like. The camera did not expect much, it's bad. But the camera is what I care less on a tablet. For me it is something useless. Samsung Galaxy Note 8.0 (16GB, White) This screen is 1280 x 720 pixels. Not as sharp as the latest Galaxy Tab 8.4 , Kindle Nexus 10 or HDX , but very colorful screen and looks pretty good. Something I really liked is reading ebooks. Also I have a Kindle Fire HDX 7, which is great for reading, but the Galaxy Note 8 so is. Being the brightest screen, thought it would be annoying to read , but to test it , I have been amazed at how good it is to read , I'm not tired eyes and I can read the text very well . Taking notes freely in the S -Note has also been a very pleasant experince , I can create as many pages as you like and keep everything in folders. Sketchbook Pro also runs very well , this tablet has a quad -core 1.6GHZ processor , 2GB RAM. This gives quite fluently , I can create multiple layers and work on large canvases smoothly. The S -pen works great , although I must admit that the sensitivity levels in these tablets is still not as good as the Bamboo, but you can make good sketches .

I purchased this for my son and he really likes it.  It was a replacement for a Sony tablet.  The clarity of the screen and speed of the tablet is keeping him very busy.  I would buy recommend this tablet.  I have iPad's and have had other Android tablets and this one is the best one I have had to date.

The main reason l chose this tablet was for the handwriting recognition, which is much better than I expected. There are times that I get to writing quickly and sloppily and l think, "I can't even read that- no way it can.'' And about half the time, it pops up the correct word. It reads both print and cursive, as well as combinations thereof. My only complaint is that it has a tendency to capitalize c, s, and m at the beginning of words. (By the way, this was written on my Note. Much more efficient than typing on it.)

Apart from that, it's about what I expected. Beautiful screen, quick responses. Big enough for easy reading, but still comfortable to hold. I do wish the split screen functionality worked with more apps, but it does well with the ones it has. Battery life is great, and it can get me through the day without needing to find an outlet. I've been getting 11-14 hours of moderate to heavy use out of it.

I usually like to point out the cons, but there really aren't many here. l would appreciate the ability to turn off touch input when the pen is out, and it does come with a lot of Samsung bloatware, but that's to be expected when buying Samsung. Some of the preloaded apps are great, such as Awesome Note (which to my surprise, turned out to be truly awesome), while others are merely annoying and useless (hello, S Voice). However, these faults are not particularly noticeable in my daily use. Granted I've not had it long enough to be out of the honeymoon phase, but as things stand, I'd buy it again.

In the summer of 2013 I bought a 7 inch Tab 2, mostly for reasons of price.  I then experienced some buyer's remorse after I saw the Note.  I waffled back and forth because it seemed self indulgent to purchase another tablet so soon.  Then I caught a good deal on a Black Friday promotion and took the plunge.  I am so glad I did.

The S-Pen really is worth it.  I tried after market styluses with both my Tab and my Ipad and they didn't have the precision (these devices also lack the digital layer that enables the S-Pen to function).  My work requires that I read and mark up PDF documents on a frequent basis.  Being able to do this with the S-Pen turns a chore into something resembling a pleasure.  The S-Pen is very accurate and my notes are legible.

Other improvements over the tab are a slimmer profile device, a MUCH longer battery life, and a better screen.  It is fast enough for my needs.  I also appreciate the expansion slot so memory can be added economically.  The big apple gouges a bit for extra memory, IMO

If I were looking for a tablet for fun and leisure, I'd go for an ipad because of the more intuitive operating system and the greater array of apps, and for streaming digital content.  However, if you want to use a tablet for work as well as play, I don't think you can beat the Samsung Note series of tablets.  The multi-screen capability (while limited) is another big plus.  I would buy another without hesitation.

I used iPad 2, iPad 3, and iPad Mini, Galaxy Tab 10.1, Galaxy Tab 7".

This tablet is overall the best 8 inch tablet on the market at the time of this review in my opinion. There is no lag at all on anything, which is a refreshing change from my Galaxy Nexus phone (which is a great phone in its own way, but I digress). If you don't mind the overpricedness, this is the perfect size for a tablet and the responsiveness is fantastic. Plus it has external storage, which is unfortunately rather rare nowadays.

The only thing holding back a perfect 5-star rating is the battery life. Even with that said, the Galaxy Note 8" delivers on the hype. The S pen is the main differentiating feature compared to other Samsung line of tablets or the Apple iPad tablets. The S pen works very well and is very smooth. Having both iPad and the Galaxy Note, I really recommend this product over the iPad due to the flexibility with the features including the S pen among other features, the Android platform it uses, and the overall quality of the product.

I got the Note 8.0 to replace my aging Galaxy Tab 7.0 Plus. What a difference! The note is fast, fast, fast. I like the little bit larger size. The WiFi is faster and stronger on the Note. With a 64Gb Micro SD card I've got plenty of storage space. I use ES Task Manager to regularly kill unused background processes and keep unused interfaces such as GPS turned off unless I need them. With these measures I get nearly two days of moderate to heavy use between battery charges. And the battery charges very rapidly. This is nowhere near the usage I get with my iPad with it's huge battery. But for an Android tablet it's quite good. I don't use the S-Pen. But clearly the screen is designed for accurate touch translation. It's much easier to use the onscreen keyboard than with my other Android devices. The touch sensor is more accurate so I get fewer inaccurate keystrokes. For any serious typing I use my foldable bluetooth keyboard and bluetooth mouse. They both connect quickly and respond well. I had to fight to get a connection sometimes with the Galaxy Tab, but not with the Note. The onscreen keyboard doesn't disappear automatically with connection of the bluetooth keyboard. You have to hit the Back key. But this is an issue with the Galaxy Tab also. It's not as smooth as is the iPad which automatically responds and retracts the onscreen keyboard upon bluetooth connection. I use an Anker portable stand with either of the tablets, and even with my Kindle. With these accessories and a Ballistic hard case on the back plus a VG nylon carrying case the Note is a great laptop replacement. I can download pictures from my Canon camera to the Note and then use my OnTheGo cable on the Note to send a second copy of my pictures to a flash drive. I'm able to keep my travel pictures safe with multiple copies. I can't do that with my iPad.

I've very happy with this tablet. I use it every day to read the NYTimes, work with email, and read a library book in the Amazon Kindle app if my wife is using the Kindle. I get a good clear voice using Skype to talk with friends around the world. This one's a keeper.

LOVE the fact that you can turn these puppies into a single remote for every room in the house. I bought the galaxy note 8.0 Refurbished. It was more than I expected. It look like a brand new tablet.

I've been looking for a tablet which matches a definition of a device where I can write notes freehand on the fly and have the notes reliably transcribed in a usable format. Unfortunately, I'm still looking, after having bought and experimented with the Samsung Note 8. I will update my review in the future as appropriate, but at this point, I'm not happy.

Using the S Note application with the S Pen for text recognition is an exercise in frustration. I tried writing a list in freehand, which would be transcribed into text. What I found was that it was difficult to fix transcription errors while writing, the transcription couldn't keep up, the margins changed randomly and the text lines would shift.

I looked for meaningful documentation that would clearly explain the functionality of the S Note application and I couldn't find any. There are a lot of buttons and options, but no clear documentation. The videos that Samsung provides are interesting, but very peripheral and don't really help someone who has bought the tablet and needs to do something with it. The videos appear to be mostly pre-sales marketing tools.

A random annoyance is that the Google Now widget displays "cards", but upon clicking the widget, the device apologies that Google Search has "stopped".

I already own an iPad 3 and was hoping this device would meet my requirements for a small device I could pull out for writing notes as needed. However I'm a disappointed with the Note 8 at this point.

Update #1 (March 16, 2014, updating rating  to 2 stars): It appears the Google Now problem is related to a recent update.  A commenter on Google Search in the "Play Store" claimed having the same problem with Google Now on a Note 8. I had cleared the Google Search cache and data to no avail.  When I backed out of the Google Search update, Google Now appeared to behave correctly.

Having dug around a bit more with the "S Note" application, I understand it better. Yet, challenges persist:
1) There is a noticeable period (perhaps an average of 2 seconds) where the tablet is working on the text recognition and the tablet is not accepting input from the S Pen.  This results in a period where one is writing freehand text, but the tablet is not recording the writing.  This makes writing more than a few words at a time frustrating.  Understanding how the text recognition algorithm works and allowing for adjustment would be helpful here.  For example, it would be useful if I could set a timer which waited for perhaps 5 seconds after the last S Pen "stroke" before attempting text recognition.
2) Looking at example "templates", the maximum number of words in the template appear to be a sentence or less. This would suggest that the software developers either didn't design the application to handle more than a sentence at a time, or there are hardware limitations which makes attempting to write more than a sentence at a time difficult.
3) A hope is that there exist other applications which work with the Note 8 that have a better text recognition workflow. As I learned when I wrote freehand text on my iPad, it's nifty that I can write this text, but it's not so nifty that my options for doing something with the writing (such as text recognition) afterwards are limiting.

A different random annoyance is that when opening up Google News with the "Internet" or "Chrome" browsers, the screen appears to initially render completely, but all of the news and headline text disappears.

In my experience, the automatic brightness adjustment causes the screen to be too dark or dim in many cases.

But over time, I had some problems with my Note 8. Battery life is HORRIBLE, first of all. And a nice display but it sucks the battery dry fast I believe.

And I never used it, once I got a Note 2 phone. The phablet serves my tablet needs just fine, fits in my pocket, and it's a phone too. So Note 8 just seems awkward to me now..

Just sold my Note 8, and got:

It's a computer, not a phone, and it's just a little bigger than the note, even with a keyboard. And it comes with WORD, EXCEL, etc already on it!
Includes an MS OFFICE license!

I'm happier now; the Note 8 was too little, too late, and I have more portability and power with my phone doubles as my tablet, and my tablet doubles as my laptop.

Tablets are not productive, but windows tablets are very productive!

I would say the ASUS T100 is an ipad killer, and an Android tablet killer both..

As a college student, I was really looking for something that did EVERYTHING without having the price to show for it. I bought my boyfriend the galaxy tab and thought it was great, so I really went back and forth trying to decide if the note was worth the extra cost.. let me just say it IS. This is Excellent for the price.  I've owned one for close to a year, and its the perfect balance between a 5" and 10".  Most people won't be happy with the resolution of the screen, but I think its just fine especially for taking notes.  Speed is fine for browsing and writing, although at times it can have trouble with intense games.

 I've owned the new Note 10.1 2014 version, and the Note 2, and I actually enjoy the Note 8.0 much better (to each their own) than either of them.  Yes the 10.1 2014 version has a nicer screen and higher specs, but if you're using this tablet for Note taking or drawing, higher everything also meant draining the battery quickly.  I just shut off the Wi-fi, turn down the screen to 35-50%, and I'm set for hours in school. Also, although the new S-note has nice new shiny excellent features, there is obvious lag in the pen, and you can't use detailed erasing when drawing like the note 8.0.  In erase mode, once you touch the current piece you have written, the eraser will remove EVERYTHING.  There are no settings to remove this.  The Note 8.0 uses very detailed erasing, and writing is very smooth.

For those that are wondering if the Note 8.0 is good for taking notes at school, I'd say yes.  I've used it through 3 hour classes no problem,  and its easy to write and erase things during class.  Once I hit 60-70%, I attach a portable battery to it and juice it back to 100%.  Place the tablet in landscape, and its easy to write.  Pinch to zoom for detailed writing and you can pan around the screen using the same two fingers while dragging them along to the spots you'd like to view (at times it feels like an old type writer when pulling the page back to the beginning of the next line).  Its great for kids to practice their ABC's, just be sure to properly protect it and keep an eye on the S-pen.

S-note is decent, but I prefer using the app Lecture Notes.  It costs $5, but well worth the cost if you like to customize your note taking and download PDF's to write over.  I sometimes download Coloring Book PDF's for my niece to draw on and save myself from buying books and crayons.  Its also great when a professor emails PDF's for class because you can highlight important information.  I'd sometimes "white out" terms, study the content, then remove the "white out" portions to check if I was correct on the term.  Its and excellent tool.

In the end, its all about personal preference.  I like the balance of an 8" tablet, vs bigger or smaller versions.  I think I spent too much money at the time I purchased this gadget, but if the tablet is in the $200 range, I'd say its worth every penny.  Spend time with it, and you'll be very happy with this device.

Very well thought out!  I am a first time user of a tablet so I am a good test subject for rating this pad.  I am finding capabilities constantly.  Using a BlueTooth qwerty keyboard with the tablet makes it a quantum leap more valuable.  Truly am glad I purchased this Galaxy Note 8.  Thank you.

This thing is awesome. I got the note instead of the tab because of the S Pen which i don't regret. It is useful for me because I needed something to easily highlight text, write notes and emails. It feels better writing and not typing and regular stylus pens on other tablets I have had don't pick up the correct text I wanted.

I had a kindle fire and then the Google Nexus 7. This is by far the best tablet I have had. I love the size. I am not a fan of the 10in tablets so this is the perfect medium. It is easy to use and sturdy. My 5 year old daughter is able to use it and can use it to practice writing. I would highly recommend this tablet.

Pros: Small form factor, long battery life, good suite of pre-installed programs, SD-card up-gradable, stylus works perfectly, lightweight, recent OS can run any Android apps (as of this writing), IR blaster for remote control capability, great stylus shortcuts, easy screen captures, practically anything can be "shared" to other apps (like Gmail, Evernote, Dropbox, etc.), bright and clear screen, very customizable interface, charges pretty quickly, makes a good e-Reader, usable for personal and professional tasks.

Cons: Templates in S-Note are very difficult to create and customize; takes some tech know-how.  It's slow to notify you of things you already knew (tells you that you plugged in headphones several minutes after the fact while watching a movie, for example). Battery is not really replaceable by the user without taking it apart. The Kit Kat Android OS hasn't been pushed out to it yet (as best I can tell).

Recommending tablets is a funny business; we all use them for different things. I am comfortable with Mac, Windows, Android, and iOS, so I can adapt. If you're an iPad-only person, this will take some time to get used to. If you're a Microsoft person, same thing. I think it's very intuitive though, and love all the shortcuts for opening apps, taking screenshots and partial screen captures, taking/editing photos on the fly, etc.  If it weren't for just a couple apps that are iPad-only, I'd switch to this device exclusively.

I do a good amount of handwriting on my tablet, so the size is becoming a limitation for me personally. Will probably upgrade to the new 12" Note Pro that was just released so I have more space to write naturally. But if you're looking for a good tablet in the 7-8" range, this one is highly recommended. I can't think of much I would suggest to the manufacturer for new features, other than a few bug fixes here or there.

BTW, I bought mine refurbished and haven't had a single issue with it.

Samsung as always provides the highest specs for any price
Works smooth and responsive
Shame it didn't have removable battery like most Samsung products do

I've been using this tablet for 6 months now mostly for taking notes in classes and meetings with an average use of a few hours a day.
The accessories: a folio case with a stylus loop holder, anti glare screen protector, and a Wacom note stylus.  I have not rooted this or used any customized ROMs.

Short review: After 6 mo, I still use this everyday for quite a few hours.  Great for note taking and pdf reading on the go.  However, those who intend to use this for hours of note taking and studying off of this should consider the 10.1 inch version, more screen real estate matters in this case.  The lack of quality accessory vendor partnership makes it harder to turn this into a full productivity work horse.

Detailed review:

The great things:
- Compact and portable, much easier than carrying a 10.1 in tablet around
- The stylus (the original and the Wacom one that I bought) work really well on the tablet.
- Palm rejection is great on this. Though sometimes your hand might hit the "back" button on the lower right next to the home button.
- I get about 6-7 hours of usage out of this

The not so great things:
- The screen resolution is not the sharpest out there, if you watch a lot of movies or need to have the best resolution, then this might not be for you. For casual users who focus mainly on taking notes and reading, I found this to be more than adequate.
- Requires to have a high output charger.  The included charger is a 2.1A one, and this won't charge when you plug it into a computer.
- Almost no big time accessory vendor partnership.  This is still a niche product, all the accessories like keyboards and such are from less known vendors. While these still work great, they add unnecessary bulk.  Zagg makes a folio keyboard for this tablet that is really good but makes it hard to use the tablet for writing and is way over priced.
- The included stylus is great but a bit too small to write comfortably for an extended period of time (>20 min).  I bought a Wacom stylus and found it to be much better, and it also has an eraser on the back so you can just use it like an eraser on the tablet.

Thoughts on taking notes:
I got this tablet to reduce the paper clutter and also to be able to remember and organize all the little notes that I take.  This tablet does all that and then some. The only adjustment that I made was make sure not to press down too hard while writing.  When writing on paper, we tend to press the ballpoint down a bit to get the ink out, but on the tablet screen this isn't required.  Once you are adjusted to that, I find myself writing faster on the tablet than on paper.

The big app on the tablet is the S Note.  My favorite feature is this "Recording" option in the app.  When you press the button, the app will record whatever your pen strokes are next.  This is fantastic for taking notes on equations or diagrams (ie those orgo reactions or physics equations) because when you hit replay, it will play back what you've written, stroke by stroke!  The downside about the app is that you can't read it easily out of the tablet. You have to manually export it as a pdf or png (image) file as the actual note file is proprietary and there aren't apps out there that can read it on a pc or mac easily.  Once you've exported, you also can't edit it.  What i find myself using more is the LectureNotes app, which is really good.  Same idea as the S Note, but you can export it more easily into Evernote.

If you are in college or taking classes and intend on using your tablet more like a productivity machine throughout your daily schedule, I would actually recommend the 10.1 inch version.  I think the 8.0 is great for meeting notes and writing on the go, but when you are dealing with hours of lectures and really have to study off of a tablet, the larger dimensions do make sense.  It is also easier to do multi window on a larger screen.  After 6 months of using this, I still find it to be fast and responsive.  The screen does heat up a bit if you are charging and using it at the same time.  I also suggest on getting a Wacom stylus, like the one here (http://www.amazon.com/Samsung-Galaxy-S-Pen-Stylus-Eraser/dp/B009QW3SGQ/ref=sr_1_6?ie=UTF8&qid=1393774422&sr=8-6&keywords=wacom+galaxy+note+stylus).  The bigger size actually makes it a lot easier to write with.

My only gripe is that there aren't many quality, thin-profiled keyboard cases for this that are reasonably priced.  Because of the lack of quality accessory vendor support, I'm taking a star away in the rating.  For high profile products like this, I take into account of how the accessory support is when considering the final rating.
It's very easy to use, transport. Was a little put off by the stylus at first, but love not having so many fingerprints on the screen now.  I love it!

The tablet itself is awesome love the s-pen and all the features. The bad though we have only had it a week and the camera is failing to  open. *** 9/19/14 ***This is an update after 6 and 1/2 months. This review was originally a 5 star review. I am knocking 3 stars off because about a month ago (when the pad was less than 6 months old), I discovered that a spot had formed on the edge of the pad. It was about an inch long and about 1/4 of an inch wide, and it appeared as though the screen was separating from the glass. I called Samsung and sure, it's under warranty, BUT you have to send it to their ONE service center in the entire US of A, and it will take 1-2 weeks to have it back. So wrong. Right?

You do not sell someone a piece of equipment that encourages them to use it to for every aspect of their life, and then tell them that when it turns out to be defective (or maybe it's junk to begin with?) that it will take 1 -2 weeks to rectify the problem. Of course, you have to save all of your data and they're not responsible for what's lost, you are responsible for insuring the device, print the label, ship it... wrong.

I decided that even though I am a bit OCD and can't take bubbles or imperfections, I had to live with it as this pad has too much on it to A) be without it for 2 weeks and B) too much that can be potentially lost forever once they mess with it. Well, I lost that choice 2 days ago when it just stopped working. I could not open the screen, nor turn it off. The screen had since "grown" two more of those bubbly patches as well. I am guessing that this problem walks hand in hand with the screen and pad not working.

I spoke to the customer service escalations dept with the first problem, and once again when it went kaput. The most that they would do is say that they would "mark it as rushed." Mmmm, bet that'll get it back here in a few days!

It is either a defective pad, or the product is just junk to begin with. Either way, Samsung should at the very least, have enough service centers that a person can have their defective product back in 3 days maximum. However, what they should do in a situation like this is, replace the thing overnight. When you claim that a product is all that and a bag of chips, then this should be automatic.

So I love the pad, as the review below explains, yet if it ends up in repair for one month out of every year, well, I will hate it. Whatever the case, I can definitively say with gusto, I hate Samsung customer service policy. I will update again.

 First Review:
This is technically the first Note Pad I've owned,  however,  my son won an ipad (the New ipad) a couple of years ago, so I do have experience with that. I definitely did not want an ipad. To me, it's just a glorified smart phone and toy that's not very smart and not much fun to play with. Apple limits the amount of real work and enjoyment one can get out of it.

When selecting a note pad, I looked for something that I could be productive with ( particularly with documents and such) whilst having the "oomph" that it takes for some reading and perhaps a movie every now and then. Not everyone who is in business,  thinks business all of the time. Not everyone who enjoys leisurely entertainment,  wants to be entertained all of the time, either.

The spen is something I don't think that I'll ever want to give up. I don't know why every pad doesn't have one. I LOVE the spen!

This little thing allows me to enjoy movies and reading without a hitch, I can create and edit documents of all types and keep myself more organized than I've ever been.  The quality,  in my opinion,  is great. I like the plastic backing and it has a perfect weight where it doesn't feel cheap or too heavy.

All in all, I don't have a bad thing to say, after owning this for a month now. Don't know how I'll feel in a few months, or next year, but right now, this is glued to me and that's where I'm happy to have it!

Great size for carrying while travelling,  holds a charge for a long time.  Was able to use it for long, cross-country flights with no problems.  Also was great substitute when my laptop needed repairs.

I am a first time user to a tablet.  I have found it hard to know how to use it to its fullest capacity.  I am sure there are many things I will never know about it.  Partly because I am afraid of screwing it up somehow.  Also, it doesn't seem like the battery life is very long and I am not familiar with how to extend the life.

It is very easy to use. I like the fact that I can download books from the library to read. The print is easy to read and it weighs much less then a paperback book. I am still experimenting with the other things it can do. I like the fact that the camera is both front and back. The wifi signal reaches through my entire house and it is nice that I can take the Galaxy Note anywere in the house. I am not stuck in one room with it. I feel it was a good investment on my part.
This does about anything I could muster up.  So I would recommend this Table to anyone who is looking for an Android device.
Bit confusing so I am still in process of watching YouTube instruction videos (which are by the way very good). I'm really too old for these gadgets but can't resist seductive technology.

Due to the well implemented Wacom stylus, I gave it one more pen than the tablet itself deserves. Otherwise, it's Android, meaning you have to charge it frequently, it's inconvenient to use and it's not very pretty. Also, it's Samsung, meaning it's glossy, looks cheap and difficult to hold. It also has sensor buttons, meaning you'll press them incidentally more often then you'd like.

I absolutely LOVE my tablet - I just wish there were more things for it like cases and such. I don't stop using this thing. The battery lasts for about all day if I'm using it to just write. If I'm playing a game it's like any other device, the battery gets cut. If you're looking for a tablet to use as a notebook and then to browse online or draw. This is the tablet for you. The stylus glides so much smoother on the 8" than the 10". And it's the perfect size.

If you are looking for a tablet to take note, make sketches, etc... this is a good option. I like this tablet because of its size, and functionality. In other words it is the tablet for work. I chose the 8" because it fits my hands and I can take it everywhere. The S-pen is really good. One app that does not work is Skype, but it is probably a minor problem compared to all of the rest of apps that do work well. I keep this one in my family room and use to when I want instant access to email, internet, photos, etc.  Great camera.  Much better viewing than a smartphone.

I almost bought the 2013 Nexus 7 but decided on this one instead and I am so glad I did.  The s-pen makes this tablet what it is.  The Wacom style digitizer makes sketching and note taking a breeze.  I draw almost daily now where I used to go through spurts of occasional drawing because I would seldom take my sketchbook with me.  Now the sketchbook is always close at hand.

For my church, I'm responsible for the leadership meeting minutes/notes and I found that writing on the note 8 is natural and less intrusive than something with a physical keyboard.  The handwriting recognition is pretty good for normal words but gets confused easily when writing out less common names/places or words unique to our faith.  Because of this, I've abandoned the handwriting to text to just handwriting in the excellent S-Note and Lecture Note apps for simplicity.  Less correcting of the incorrect auto-correct that way.  For short notes or writing in other apps the handwriting recognition is good enough.

Other aspects of the tablet are fine. The IR port works but is kind of irrelevant to me as I seldom watch TV with it.  Screen resolution is plenty sharp for my near-sighted eyes.  The processor is quick and snappy and I've barely used up much of the 16gb (more like 8 or 9 after all the preloaded Samsung stuff).  I have an SD card to expand the memory but haven't needed much of that space either except for my growing collection of sketches.  The expandability is nice if I ever do run out of space.

Overall I love the tablet as it allows me to create content easily and not merely consume it.  That capability from the s-pen and active digitizer make all the difference to me.  Worth the price.

I'm so happy with this product. My tablet came a day earlier than expected. For a used tablet it looks extremely new. Came in lovely condition.. the tablet is very easy to use.. being I'm already familiar with Samsung products. If This will be your first tablet there is definitely a learning curve to the tablet. Only thing I didn't like was when it was delivered I never even received an email notification... and I was under the impression that a adult signature was required for delivery. But instead I came home on one of the coldest day of the week atleast -10 degrees outside... with my tablet package sitting outside my side door.

If you don't have a strong need for an active stylus, this tablet isn't worth the price. On the other hand, if you plan on writing digitally, it's perfect. I use it for all my notes and homework at university. I've never had any complaints about performance or battery life. (In fact, I rarely get it below 50% in a day). The stylus is very accurate. The size seems perfect for a tablet. Much bigger, and I might as well use my laptop, but any smaller and it would be hard to use. It even fits in my coat pocket! All the Samsung junk is a bit annoying, but you can disable most of the things through the Application Manager in settings.

Some tips if you want to use it for taking notes:
  - I find the app LectureNotes the most capable Android application for note-taking. The full version is $5 I think, but when you just bought a $300 tablet, what's another 5? It easily lets you import PDFs to write on, and you can export as PDF to print to share. By using another application called DropSync, it will sync all your notes to Dropbox (which you get an extra 50GB from buynig this tablet), viewable on your computer.
  - I bought a separate stylus to make long writing sessions more comfortable. It's the "Bamboo Stylus Feel for Samsung Galaxy Note". Be sure you get the one with the product code CS300UK2, not CS300UK, because it will not write accurately. It's only available from Wacom's website.
I bought this tablet for my boyfriend and he loves it. It's great for when he does paperwork for work. I would definitely recommend this product. It even came earlier then expected,  it was perfect.
smooth, fast, and replaces the ipad. does everything and anything. no lagg, awesome cam quality. Plays HD beyond fine. idk what more to say.

I bought it as a replacement for my nexus 7(1st gen) because it couldn't connect to my tv. I use this for all sorts of things like streaming videos and taking down notes during meetings. Quick Background: our household owns/uses the following: older generation Nexus 7, newer generation Nexus 7, this note, and the Sony Xperia (10 inch). Of all the tablets that I've owned, used or looked into, this is my favorite...

Also, in case it's useful: I primarily use the tablet for taking notes, sending emails, reading, playing games, and sometimes, watching movies...

Pros:

1. Love the stylus -- I find it so useful for emails, etc. I've gotten amazingly fast with swype etc and actually get frustrated when I have to actually type-type with my thumbs, on a smart phone!!!

2. It's a great size for most of the activities I like -- I use a kindle app for reading (other apps as well sometimes), it's great for watching movies, etc and wonderful for all the little stupid games I'm addicted to.

3. It's generally light-weight and travels well

4. Takes pictures etc well, though I honestly use that feature very, very rarely as I find it to be an awkard size for that particular function.

5. This is a sillier one, but as a mom, I love the photo wall feature that zips through the pictures of my kids I have... (though I'm sure it's part of my battery-life-problem, see below)

Cons:

1. Mostly just the battery life. I think the battery on both of my Nexus(es) was better. When I've been really gaming, etc. it feels like the batter just drains.

2. Though I've had my current one for a few months, the first one I bought actually had to be sent back (its battery drained within the hour) but I had no problems returning it, liked it enough to ask for the replacement (as opposed to just refund) and have loved this one.

Omg this thing is so friggen awesome...  totally worth the money and best to get it from amazon bc its free shipping and no tax!  this thing is totally cool.  Easy to figure out, within a matter of a couple hours I was controling my tv with it, watching tv on it and had it completely customized to my own liking! AMAZING DEVICE!!!

I love the Note 8.0, it is great for college. It is the right size, easy to carry and use. The stylus is great, I do a lot of handwriting with it. Would highly recommend it if you are looking for a good college tablet, or for recreational uses.

S-pen - is something incredible! Everything is very convinient! Note works fast, support all modern games without any problems. 8 inch display is comfortable enough to play games, browse Internet, read books and even painting. I am really pleased with Samsung Note.

So far so good with this tablet.  Performance is flawless and I have experiences no glitches of any kind.  I got the Samsung note mostly because of the note/stylus feature and also because, unlike almost every other tablet out there, it has an SD slot so you can add up to 64 GB more storage.  By comparison, the iPad mini with 64 GB of built-in storage will run you about $500 and if the note feature of the Samsung is important to you then you will be missing out on that too.  So when you compare this tablet with others, make sure you are comparing machines with the same features or the comparison will not mean much.

My only regret is that I didn't just go ahead and get the 10.1 (2014 edition) version since the 8.0 can be a bit small at times.  The trade off is the fact that the 8.0 is a bit more portable and of course lighter but I think I would have rather have traded the slight loss of portability for the extra screen size.  If you are considering an 8" tablet, give this some thought.  Its not like you can put the 8.0 in your pocket anyway so you don't lose a whole lot by stepping up to the larger size (other than the increased price, of course.)  But all in all, I'm happy with it and I plan to keep it until such time as I am ready for a new one.  At that time, I will almost certainly go with a larger size of whatever model is current at that time.

I was excited to get this gift for my husband.  He  absolutely loved it until the glitching started.  You will be lucky to use this device for 15 minutes without it shutting down and rebooting.  So annoying. ....especially when you're in the middle of something important.  Will be returning

I have enjoyed plenty of modern tablets. Everything from iPads, Galaxy Tabs, to Sony's Xperia Z. This is by far the most comprehensive tablet I have owned to date. You will find better entertainment specs on different tablets like the iPad, but if you want something that can be used for EVERYTHING, the Note 8 is the way to go. I mean, the resolution is just fine for enjoying movies and games (people often complain because this doesn't stack up to something like the Nexus or Retina display). I love this thing. I love the S Pen. I love the handwriting to text features. I love the size. I love being able to shove this into my jacket pocket and rock out to my favorite tunes using wireless bluetooth earbuds. This has been one of those purchases that has been perfect in every aspect for me. I mean, this is the first time I have ever agreed to write a review.

I never write reviews but I had to. This tablet is the greatest invention ever. I can use it for work, personal, netflix, etc. The battery life is great and the pen is perfect for writing. I use it everyday it fits in my purse and can hold more memory. I recommend buying one because it packs a bang for the buck.

S Note is great for taking notes and keeping memos. Evernote can be used for other purposes such as grocery lists that can be shared between family members. Skype is always available. Fast wi-fi access. I love it!

I have been purchasing Sam Tabs since the Galaxy Tab 2 7.  Since then I have had the Tab 2 10.1 and the famous and wish they would have kept improving Tab 7.7 which I still have. I also have the Note 2 and a first gen iPad. I wouldn't have even purchased the Note 8 if I had not cracked my screen on the 7.7.  Glad I did purchase it though.  It's faster and showed the age of my 7.7 with how it handles the whole experience of using a tablet.
  I won't go thru all the tech stuff that many have submitted.  But I can address the issue of the upgrade to Jellybean 4.2.2.  Samsung must have corrected the problem that many have described where the multi-window functionality stopped working after installing it.  Mine not only worked fine but to my surprise and pleasure, the unit installed all my apps that I had on my 7.7 and afterwards installed the upgrade with no loss of data.  It even restored all my photos that i had on my other units;
I purchased the Moko slim case with a magnet.  It may be a little early to tell if it's the magnet or not but every now and then when I fold the flap in back of the tablet hand touches are nonresponsive.  Oddly enough though, the pen still worked.  If I turn it off and back on again the hand touches worked again.  I will use it without the case for a day or 2 to see if that is the problem.  I heard this unit has had problems with magnetized covers.  Otherwise, the experience I have with this tablet is very similar to what I have with the Note 2.  Excellent.  My only gripe is that it didn't come with a better display.  The colors are beautiful and reading text are sharp but the movie experience is no where near as crisp as the Note 2 or even as crisp as my Galaxy 7.7.
  Another complaint that i have read is the size of the bezel.  What a silly quibble.  My 7.7 has the exact same size bezel and it was haled as one of the best tablets of its time.  The thing cost $700 without contract when it came out and now we pay 3-400 for a tab that is more powerful and feature rich and complain it cost too much.  i tried using the other tablets with a thinner bezel and my hand kept touching the darn screen activating various apps I didn't want loaded.
Plastic is another issue.  Almost all tablets are made of either plastic or aluminum or a combination of the 2.  Look and feel are subjective preferences but to use a tablet without having a protective cover is not very wise imho. Once you place a cover on it, look and feel go out the window anyway.
One more quibble.  Battery life.  Not the greatest.  The note 2 lasts all day with heavy use.  I have never been able to max it out even watching movies, surfing, gaming, using the phone etc.  The Note 8 not so much.  You have to put it on power saving mode to get the best life out of it.  I have only had it for 2 days and I already had to charge it once and right now it's at 74%.  Shame on you Samsung.  My Galaxy 7.7 gets better battery life.  But then again it has a super amoled plus display that uses less power with more punch in color and vibrance.  Better blacks too.
Even with these caveats, the Note 8 is a great tablet to use and since it is a tablet and not a phone you get true "desktop" web browsing, more screen realestate and Samsung Note apps and usability to boot.  Not bad for $289.  If you want the magazine UI you can download Chameleon Launcher and get the best of both worlds.  Just thought I'd through that in for free.  The launcher needs a little work but it does change the way you see and utilize your tablet.  Better categorizing of home screens etc.

Would I recommend the Note 8.0?  Now that you can get at a price point that competes with iPad mini, Nexus 7 and LG G8.3... Yeahhh!

I had it narrowed down to this tablet, the Galaxy Note 10.1 (2014), and possibly an iPad (comparable in price to the Note 10.1).

I saw this one for $230, factory refurbished. The price was irresistible.

I couldn't be happier. I was concerned that the screen was a little to small. I use this mainly for watching videos (often on plane rides) and grading papers (college-level Math homework).

I got a (free) Android app for annotating PDF's that I use to grade papers electronically. Having the stylus is indispensable for this purpose, especially because it's very difficult to type Mathematical symbols into any word processor. One can use typesetting software, but this is very impractical when you just want to grade papers.

Streaming video over wifi (ESPN3, HBOGO, Netflix) works very well. For plane rides, the Android video player works very well. I have to convert some video files to mp4, but there is viable software on the internet (cost-free) to do this. The battery has been more than sufficient for flying coast-to-coast (unlike my old laptop's battery).

I highly recommend the Galaxy Note 8.0. I was a little concerned that the screen would be too small, but I find it to be perfect for my purposes. I like Apple products very much, but I don't think I would be as satisfied with an iPad for its lack of stylus and inflexibility with video playback. (And no, I'm not converting back to Windows or Linux, I still love my MacBook and I'll get another when it dies (6 years and going).)

I own an iPad 1st gen and recieved this as a birthday present. After long and extensive research, I thought this tablet would be the perfect tablet for my school needs. I already own and iPhone 5s, so buying another iPad just seemed like having a giant version of my phone. After playing with my new tablet I can only think of two real issues with the tablet.

Pros:
-Perfect purse size tablet
-Small and light
-S-pen is an amazing feature
-Quick response time
-great screen resolution
-samsung sends emails about different features supported by the note 8

Cons:
-it is 16gb before all the preinstalled apps provided by samsung. After realizing that the approximately free 9gb would not be enough space for me, I invested in a 32gb sd card. If considering this tablet, the sd card is a much needed accessory.
-certain cases distort s-pen functionality. The resolution to this problem is to look for cases that do not have a magnet in the design.

Honestly, I'm happy I recieved this tablet and I would recommend this tablet to others. However, do your own research before buying an expensive product like this. The Note 10.1 2014 edition was just released before I bought this one, but I liked the size of this one over the Note 10.1.

Nice screen but not my cup of tea.  A little too big for my hand. So sold it right away after receiving it.  Liked the tab2 better had it have a faster processor. U get more bangs for ur bucks than the iPad tho.

It happens. The battery on my Note has lasted 2-3 hours at best since I've owned it. I contacted the seller (3rd party) about the issue and they were quick to respond. Fast, smooth, and what I hoped for in a smaller portable tablet.  The split screen is excellent.  The stylus is very useful; takes a bit of practice.  Apps noted as optimized for phone work very well on this tablet (just bigger).

Easy to set up out of the box, be ready to log in your Samsung and Google accounts.  Will then import in all your Google and Samsung apps and info.

One quirk to be prepared to handle - some users, including me, have a problem when the tablet automatically upgrades from android 4.1.2 (out of box) to 4.2.2.  This happens right away.  I soon noticed that the multi screen feature and the quick screen did not work.  Could not fix.  Went to blogs and learned that this is a known problem (thanks Samsung).  The solution is not as scary as it sounds.  Go to settings,backup and select factory reset.  Reinstalls 4.1.2.  Will automatically update to 4.2.2 again, but this time without the error noted above.  Joy, except you now have to set up the tablet all over again.  Any apps and preferences you earlier set have to be redone.  Cost me a half hour or so.

Once past that unpleasantness, great experience and great tablet.  Definitely get the Google keyboard as it is superior to the Samsung keyboard; Swype is so fast.

The processor is fast! The integration is excellent.  Widgets are excellent.  The Google apps work well together (definitely look into most all of them). Along with the S pen, It comes with a variety of other useful features, like the multi-window function that allows two apps to be open at once side-by-side (which is awesome to me);an infrared blaster, which can have the device as a remote control to any tv; and the eye sensor, which keeps the screen on as long as you're looking at it. I took the plunge on a refurbished Note 8 and couldn't be happier. I have owned many pen devices over the years, from the original Compaq iPaq, IBM Wacom based Thinkpads, and the original Galaxy Note phone. I'm going to start this review by saying don't buy this tablet if you don't want a pen based device... there are cheaper options that will fill the tablet role without the added cost of the Wacom pen. If you are still reading, I'll assume you want a device with a real pen. The Note 8 is the perfect size for a note taking device. The Galaxy Note I phone I own and love just wasn't big enough to make the pen really useful for me. The design of the tablet is simple, with gently curved corners and a fairly wide bezel. The lack of an easily removable back provides decent rigidity that makes it feel less creaky than my phone. The back can be removed for a fairly easy battery replacement... but it is not meant to be swapped in and out like a phone battery. I wish Samsung didn't put the big chrome logo on top, but it is what it is. The pen is slightly longer and fatter than the pen that comes with the Note phones. It is mostly round, with a flat side where the button is. The tip of the pen has a nice texture which adds some drag when used on the glass. The nib is not replaceable with standard Wacom nibs. I personally use a Wacom pen that I purchased for my laptop. It has the eraser on one end and replaceable nibs. It is the size of a standard pen, and obviously won't fit in the tablets pen holder. I find it much nicer to write with than the provided pen. From an inking perspective, the pen is accurate for me. I'm left handed and I don't have any issues with the alignment of the nib and on-screen cursor position. There is some minor lag if you are drawing fast where you may notice the ink takes a fraction of a second to catch up. It's not horrible, but may be noticeable and annoying if you are expecting the device to be just like ink and paper. In truth, it's pretty fast compared to other Wacom devices I've used. I *always* put a screen protector on my pen devices... while the glass is durable, all it takes is a small grain to get caught on your tip or eraser to make a scratch. I am using the iSmooth Samsung Galaxy Note 8 Ultra Clear Premium HD Screen Protector 2 Pack which is working out well. If you are looking for a case, check out the MoKo Slim Cover Case for Samsung Galaxy Note 8.0 inch GT - N5100 Android Tablet, Black (with lip Stand, Integrated Elastic Hand Strap, and Stylus Loop)-Lifetime Warranty. It fits well and the brown leather looks nice in contrast to the white tablet. There is some talk about the magnets in many of the cases interfering with the s-pen, possibly even causing permanent problems, so I took an exacto knife and carefully removed them from the case. On the application side, S-Note is where the Note 8 makes the S-Pen shine. It does everything you would expect a note taking app to do, including the ability to export notes to a pdf for sharing with non S-Note users. The only thing missing for me feature in Microsoft One Note where it translates your ink in the background and makes your handwritten notes searchable. From a general perspective of tablet use, the Note 8 works fine. The lcd is sharp and has great viewing angles. Video playback is smooth and the device feels very snappy in general. I appreciate that Samsung still provides a micro sd slot... it is becoming too rare these days. As is normal for Samsung, they add in their usual bloatware apps that can't be removed. While you can root the Galaxy Note 8, if you install an Android rom like Cyanogenmod you will loose the ability to run S-Note and many of the other tightly integrated s-pen features. Samsung tends to be stingy with their OS updates, and I'll be surprised if they support the device after 4.4 Kitkat. The battery is good, but not stellar. Be careful with apps that provide background notifications/updates as they will chew away at your battery when the tablet is idle. In summary, the Note 8 is almost perfect for me. If Microsoft released a fully functional version of One Note for Android I would be in heaven, but it will never happen. The Surface Pro is just too big and expensive for what I need. At the current price, the refurbished Note 8 is about the same price as a good new 7" tablet without a pen, which seems like a great deal to me.

Small enough that I can hold in one hand and write with other with S-pen or pop-up keyboard. Large enough to split screen between multiple spots. Love that I can write a document in one app window and look up facts/references/calendar in other window. Really useful.

Very happy with the bright and colorful display and decent camera. I'm not a game player but I've been very pleased watching videos.

Next project: to use with my home computer network and A/V streaming to TV via CromeCast or DLNA. One disappointment: the IR blaster and Peel remote. For me I have to be close (~6') for reliable control; and Peel setups don't handle my standard Panasonic smart Blu-ray player, and set-top box interface is clunky. Trusting that remote apps will do the job over Wi-Fi.

I once read that Apple said they would never produce an iPad smaller than 10" because that's what they determined through studies to be the best.

Since getting the Note 8, I hardly use my iPad at all.  In fact, I now find it to be heavy and clunky when compared to the Note.

I have found this to be the perfect size as I can hold it in one hand, or not feel like I'm cradiling a TV tray in both hands.  It's perfect for games and the resolution is amazing.

Battery life is much better than my Galaxy S3, considering that the Note 8 is a quad-processor.

Very solid device and does not feel cheap, despite the plastic back.

The S-Pen is very nice and responsive.  I like how the device turns on and unlocks when the pen is removed.  Pen location is located in the bottom right corner.  One would expect it to be at the top of the device, but being able to pull down instead of pull up seems to be more ideal.  When pen is docked, it blends seemlessly with the rounded corner.  Easily detaches by running your fingernail down.

For the price, you would definately want to check into the Note 8 if you are looking at a Nook or Fire, as those reader apps are available on the Note.

Great tablet. Love size and convenience and all of its features. Especially like the S-pen. Great way of inputting on the go!

This highlights some of the Apps that are "NEED TO HAVES" if you make the wise choice of buying this tablet.  With the Note 8 and these Apps, I haven't used my Desktop since.

NEED TO HAVE Apps for the Samsung Galaxy Note 8

mazec3**

This App replaces your keyboard and enables you to hand write in every App, email and on the internet using the S/Pen.  Most people have difficulty reading my hand writing and yet this App is able to consistently convert it into text. I find that hand writing with mazec3 on the Note 8 is noticeably faster than tapping or swipping on a keyboard.  With this App and the Note 8, you'll get more done than you could on any other tablet.

**It is worth noting that the Samsung keyboard does have a native handwriting recognition mode built in (you can find it in the keyboard's settings).  However, instead of writing continuously, you can only input a couple words at a time.  It's reliable - but it will slow you down.

Polaris Office

This App comes pre loaded on the Note 8 but I am highlighting it to urge you to use it...because it is so amazing.  I have tried several Apps to create and edit Word, Excel, and PowerPoint documents-nothing comes close to Polaris Office.  It is extremely easy to use and the editing tools closely mirror the Office Desktop Software.  So far, I haven't found anything that I used to do on my desktop that I haven't been able to do with Polaris Office.  In fact, when combined with mazec3, I prefer Polaris Office to the desktop.

G Cloud

This App backs up all of your files including documents, music, contacts etc... Just install it on all your devices - including your old tablet, then back-up all your files and you can easily download any of the files on the Note 8. I also use Drop Box, but the reason I love this App is because I can easily get my music from my past and present devices onto my Note 8 and my documents are backed up daily so I can't lose anything.

mSecure

This App stores all your passwords and log in information.  What makes this App stand out from the pack (and will save you time) is that from mSecure in a click or two you can instantly login to your favorite Websites-without having to open your browser, type in the URL, and type in your login info... mSecure does all the work for you.  I also used to use the same 2-3 passwords over and over.  With mSecure, I now have unique passwords for all my logins using their password generator.  I no longer use my desktop to login to online banking or web applications... it's faster and easier on the Note 8.

I hope this gives you a better idea of what is possible with the Note 8.  You are going to love it!

Other Apps to Consider if the Note 8 is your First Tablet:
-Google Voice Search
-Drop Box
-Dolphin Browser
-EverNote
-CalenGoo
-Glympse

There was little doubt that I was going with the Samsung Note, but which size? I am thrilled so far (been a few days) that I chose the 8.0 ( GT-N511). So much nicer than my ancient 10 inch Acer. Beware that you probably DO NOT want to upgrade the OS to 4.2.2. The original came with 4.1.2, but when I upgrade to 4.2.2, the awesome Smart Dock turned dunce. Samsung Customer Service said that the Smart Dock isn't compatible, but there are videos of people having success with the Note 8.0 and Smart Dock...they were using Android 4.1.2 though! And there is no way to downgrade unless you Root/Flash the device (which voids the warranty). So buyer beware.
So if you don't care about the Smart Dock incompatibility, then this is your tablet!

I love the tablet. The charger broke within the first month. Fortunately I have other micro USB chargers I was able to use.

Fool me once, shame on you. Fool me twice shame on me. I design apps for a living and I bought the Samsung Galaxy Note 8 Tablet as a test device because so much of my negative feedback stems from this model. After unboxing the device, I initially had no idea what users were complaining about. The hardware is solid and beautiful and everything works as promised.

Of course, this honeymoon period was short lived and now I cringe everytime I pick up this device. There are things that work fine on other Android Tablets that just simply defy explanations on the Samsung Galaxy 8.

BLOATWARE:
I should have known better but, true to form I too started to experience the same issues with Samsung that my users were experiencing. First, the sheer volume of Samsung "bloatware" that ships with the tablet is amazing. These are Samsung branded apps that take up storage space on your device that you might never use. Granted SOME of the apps are useful but most just take up space. It is as if Samsung doesn't realize there's a whole Google Play store that users can access anytime they need a new app. Yes, there is a micro SD port that allows me to expand my storage capacity but, it'd be nice if Samsung just allowed users to delete all of it's bloatware if the user doesnt use them. Period. (Note that this type of behavior is not isolated to Samsung. Many device manufacturers -- from HTC to the Carriers do the same thing.)

FIRMWARE and SOFTWARE (OPERATING SYSTEM) UPDATES:
Unlike Google Nexus Devices, the Galaxy Note 8.0 is a slave to the device manufacturer. What this means is, if Google releases a new update to their Android software  you can't just download it and experience the benefits right away. You have to wait until Samsung releases their own version of the update before you have access to it on your Samsung device. Most of the time, its because they have to test their own "bloatware" to see if it works on the new update. If it doesn't they need to retool their apps BEFORE they release the updates. If you don't use Samsung's bloatware apps, this can be more than frustrating.
(Sure you can 'root' the device and override this issue  but, if you bought this to experience how most people would use the device, then rooting it defeats the whole purpose of using it as a test device.)

CUSTOMER SERVICE is ABOMIDABLE:
You may, overtime (for me it was within 90 days) start experiencing problems where your tablet starts to crash incessantly (you'll see the dreaded "Unfortunately Cloud Agent Has Stopped" message.) When you get online with Customer Service they will run you through a script (this is true for most Customer Service centers) as they try to diagnose just what is wrong with your device as well as what they can do to fix your problem(s).

However, if you're an experienced Android user, you've most likely already gone online and done your due diligence and searched through user forums and found a bevy of unhappy Samsung Galaxy Note 8 owners with the same complaints/issues that you're experiencing. Most likely that means you've already updated your software, already power cycled (turn it off and then on again), completed a factory reset and a myriad of other quick fixes on your customer service representative's script.

Having done all of the above, THIS is when your customer service rep starts grasping at straws to explain why your device may be misbehaving (phantom touches, screen lock-ups, crashes). And the solutions flung out at you range from blaming the magnets in your device case (which by the way is a SAMSUNG branded case specifically for the Galaxy Note 8) to blaming the micro-SD card (Im using a SanDisk Ultra) to telling you to delete all your apps and start from scratch (not a desirable process).

MAYBE ITs A FLUKE
Having exhausted most of my patience, I decided (foolishly) that maybe my device was a lemon. One built on the last shift of the last day of the work week. These things happen. SO I bought a second Samsung Galaxy Note 8  this time from an actual bricks and mortar retailer (BestBuy)  and just like my previous experience, it was great out of the box but, performance would start to lag in just a matter of days. It didn't matter that I killed all uneccessary tasks, was running only one app at a time, had RAM to spare, 10+ GB of open storage (more if you factor in the SD card), or even limited the specific apps I downloaded  the NEW Samsung Tablet acted much like it's twin I purchased online.

Keep in mind Im not running anything out of the ordinary on these tablets, Im just using my Bank's Bill Pay app, Readability, Facebook, Twitter, Mint, DropBox, Evernote, IMDB, Hulu+, Netflix, HBO Go, the Google Apps Suite (Play, Google+, HangOuts, Chrome etc.)

RESULTS MAY VARY
Yet from the other reviews you read here, you'll see some people are having a grand time and flawless performance with their Samsung Galaxy Note 8 -- so your results may vary. But for me personally, the Nexus devices work best  the Samsungs are too tempermental for my taste. When they work, they're a joy to use. When they don't work, I feel like flinging it across the room.

We shopped at best buy and couldn't get anyone to wait on us. So I pulled out my phone and looked this product up on amazon and was surprised to see exactly what I wanted and $50 less than best buy. It was a Christmas gift for our daughter and she loves it! It will be a big help to her as she returns to college in a few days. I would recommend it to everyone who wants a note or tablet.

I've been using this tablet for over 6 months now and still absolutely love it.  In my mind this is the *only* mid-size tablet that gets pen input right, which is unique.  The digitizer based screen is a HUGE benefit and makes note taking or sketching very pleasant.  I use this every day for taking notes and it actually works -- fast and accurate.  AND one of the least-often touted advantages of the digitizer is the fact you can *hover* buttons in a browser, so pull-downs and other menus are actually usable.  No other tablet -- iPad or otherwise -- can do that.

I have also looked at tablet PCs from Microsoft, Sony, etc but keep coming back to the Galaxy Notes as the best option for portability, features, app selection, and price.  Even now after the release of Nexus 7 and iPad mini retina I still think this is the best tablet for artists or note takers.  If you just need a tablet for touch, I agree with other reviewers that you can get a better bang for the buck with a Nexus 7 or non digitizer-based tablet.

Of course, no product is perfect so here are some things I would want in the next version:
- Higher res screen, 1080p or better
- Bigger stylus with more weight (I bought a separate Samsung stylus, don't use the original)
- Better battery life -- I get about 1 day with heavy use, 2 days with light use, 2.5 days at standby.  Would prefer 3-4 days of juice.
- Better case/cover options -- the official Samsung case is flimsy and others are not as high quality as iPad equivalents
